story:
The Story

Paja, Spaho and Niklovani were teenagers and young men when the war began in Bosnia and Herzegovina in the spring of 1992. They suddenly found themselves holding weapons and defending their Olympic city, Sarajevo, as it endured the longest siege in modern history (1425 days). The war ended in November 1995 with a peace agreement made in Dayton, Ohio.

Today they are middle-aged, and have had children, marriages and divorces. They have cook-outs up in the mountains where they used to fight.  The days in the siege were the best and the worst in their lives, as they look back on the past and forward to the second halves of their lives in a country with an uncertain future.

This November diplomats and talking heads in the US and Europe are celebrating 20 years of post-war peace in Bosnia.

But what do the guys who were forced to fight think about life and peace 20 years later?

No one invited these guys to Dayton in 1995 - but they’re going to the US this month to tell their story and ask questions.

***

We’re sending these three guys to the United States to ask questions and get answers.  The team is visiting New York City, Dayton, and Washington, DC. We’re meeting journalists, policymakers, professors and artists. We’re also participating in the “Dayton Peace Accords at 20” conference at the University of Dayton.

In addition to asking some serious questions, we want to have some fun: we want to see how long Spaho can go without a cigarette; how Niklovani will react to a Starbucks menu; and how long it will take Paja to get slapped by a woman in a bar.

Think Michael Moore meets Borat.

We’re couch-surfing. The team is all volunteer. Your contribution can help us with filming, pre-and post-trip logistics, and will help us eat more than street vendor hotdogs while stateside. We would also like to ensure solid trailers, post-production quality, and aggressive distribution, and will professionalize the crew as much as possible while maintaining our creative vision.

Our team has the skills we need: An extroverted barfly. A political junkie. A television director. An Internet addict. A chain smoker. A former puppet wrangler. A guy who polished his gun with sandpaper during the war to make it shiny.

Bosnia is not unique; normal people are currently suffering at the hands of warlord politics in Syria, Iraq, Libya and other global hotspots. What will their countries look like when the shooting stops?????

We can learn from these guys.

Help us to change the way people think about war, peace and international policy.

Help us to show the side of war and peace you DON’T usually hear about.

And meet a fun group of guys who will make you want to come party in Sarajevo.

The Process

The all-volunteer team has a 5-stage process to make this vision a reality, and your donation will support this initiative from beginning to end:

1. Pre-trip

We’ve contacted policy-makers, professors, journalists and others in Washington, New York and Dayton, Ohio to set up interviews. We’ve filmed interviews with people in Sarajevo to ask them what questions the team should ask while in the US. We’ve done some initial scene-setting filming as well. The guys have received visas to travel to the US (for the first time!), and we’ve found free accommodations to help us keep costs down.

2. The Trip

We flew to the US on November 14. After 2 days in NY City to talk to people familiar with Bosnia, we came to Dayton, Ohio itself to see where this peace agreement was born. We’re participating in the Dayton commemorative conference, together with Bill Clinton and lots of other VIPs. Then we head to Washington DC to meet some of the people who shaped policies and the peace then and now.

We also expect to have some fun – introducing the boys to some of what America has to offer. 

3. Post-Trip

When we get back we’ll sit down with the group and process the experience. We’ll also film some post-travel interviews and discussions to figure out how to hit the right mix of humor and history, and the right blend of the personal and the political.

4. Post-Production

Once we have our footage we’ll begin post-production editing, with the goal of a 60-minute film. The more we raise, the higher quality we’ll be able to achieve – we will do what we can, but would love to tell this story with top quality editing, color correction, audio engineering and mixing and maybe even some original scoring.

We’ll also do test screenings in Sarajevo and other parts of BiH as we refine and edit the film to make sure the story makes the impact we know it can make.

5. Distribution

Our audience is broad – the comedy will show a side of Bosnia many people don’t know, and the serious topics covered will appeal to viewers interested in international issues of war and peace.

We expect a strong showing on the festival circuit, in Sarajevo and the region, as well as in the US.

Why it Matters

Sometimes it seems the world is getting more crazy and violent every day. Bosnia’s experience offers a lot of lessons for other countries going through violent conflict and political transition. What’s the right way to end a war, not for the warlords but for the normal people whose lives are affected by it? It’s time we heard their perspective, and put them at the table.

The Team

Mofoco (Movies for Communities) is a small, innovative film crew based in Sarajevo. Four people make up the core team for this film:

Valery Perry (Producer/Director)

Valery was born in Buffalo, New York, and has lived in Sarajevo since 1999. Her PhD focused on Bosnia’s post-war political reconstruction, and she has worked throughout the country on various democracy and human rights initiatives. Her professional and academic work targets a narrow policy audience, and she’s now using film to get more people interested in international issues that increasingly affect us all.

Sue Folger (Associate Producer)


Sue spent over a decade in Moscow during its tumultuous post-Cold War transition, as a student, magazine editor, translator, teacher and field producer for CBS News. She worked in Ukraine before coming to Sarajevo in 2010 to work on a media development project. She holds a Master’s degree in Russian Language and Literature and Certificate of Advanced Study in Russian Translation from SUNY-Albany, and has a BA from Mt. Holyoke College.

Pavle “Paja” Fukarek (Actor/Creative Director)


Paja was born in Sarajevo and was studying forestry science when the war broke out. He was in the army throughout the war, and then lived, worked and travelled in Italy, Croatia and elsewhere. He speaks fluent Italian. He’s worked in a number of logistical, managerial and technical positions in the region, travelled as a roadie supporting various bands and artists in the region, and has sung professionally in bars in and around Sarajevo. He also provides tourism support to people visiting Bosnia and Croatia.

Erol Gagula (Director of Cinematography)


Erol was born in Sarajevo, and lived and fought here throughout the siege. He has worked in television production for a major Bosnian public broadcaster for 20 years. His Master’s thesis looked at communication and tourism promotion, and he’s started a motorcycle tourism effort in Bosnia to attract more visitors and show off the country’s great scenery and food.

Armina Mujanovic (Social media manager/Translator/tech Support)

Armina Mujanović received her undergraduate degree in political science, and has worked with civil society organisations throughout Bosnia on their inclusion in constitutional reform processes. She has maintained and created various online profiles of non-formal coalitions and organizations, including  the Initiative for Free Declaration and the Democratization Policy Council. Even though tech savvy, she is still learning.

story:
Hats & Scarves Campaign....

Mission Statement

Brixton Soup Kitchen is a grassroots organisation helping homeless people and Londoners in need. It provides food, support and company with no obligation attached. It aims to empower people in a warm and friendly environment.  

·  Grass-roots: Founded and run by Brixtoners who are truly part of the community

  • Food: Free food and drink for those that struggle to provide for themselves
  • Support: IT facilities, CV workshops, housing and benefits advice
  • Company: Friendly faces to shat to and shoulders to lean on
  • No obligation: You don’t have to prove your living situation or pray for your food
  • Empower: Help people get back on their feet


Who we are

Brixton Soup Kitchen was founded in January 2013, when Solomon Smith a Lambeth youth worker and lifelong Brixtonian realised there was a desperate need for such an organisation. We are based in Brixton Social Club and currently open three days a week. We offer so much more than hot food and drinks; we provide CV workshops, job guidance and advice on housing and benefits.

What we’ve done in our first year

-Served up to 50 people a day food and hot drinks

-Distributed care packages to those in need

-Received regular food donations from Greggs, Pret a Manger and Nando’s

-Become equipped with modern computer facilities for guests to use

-Helped 3 people get back into full time employment

-Bought a bicycle for a man who would walk 3 hours to the Soup Kitchen

-Solomon has received the South London ‘Our Heroes’ Award in 2013 and Co-Director Mahamed Hashi has been nominated for the 2014 award

-Delivered food to families in need

What we want to achieve

2014:

  • Raise funds for a van to distribute food and care to the homeless across the Lambeth borough
  • Become a registered charity
  • More extensive staff training

Beyond:

  • Become a recognised support centre for the community as a whole.
  • Provide extra facilities including job search support, advice on housing and benefits and a night shelter for those in dire need.
  • Acquire funding to allow us to be able to apply for passport renewals, provisional licences and other forms of essential ID.

Our Aims...

Winter is very hard on the homeless that roam the streets by day and desperately try to keep warm by night. Their plight is especially tough during the Holiday season when they are so alone with no family, no Thanksgiving feast, no warm Christmas cheer from friends, no gifts under a Christmas tree. Many only have faint childhood memories to fill their souls.

We met Liam sleeping in the bins 2:30am in East London

Brixton Soup Kitchen does outreach in and around London, Lately has become very cold on the streets of London and for that reason we want to buy warm hats, gloves, scarves to help keep the homeless warm this winter.


Last year we gave out 780 Hats & Scarves in and around London and this year we want to give out 1,200


What We Need & What You Get

The reason why we need £5500 is.....

We need £5500 of materials and transport to complete this project..
Embroidery BSK logo set up £140
Gloves, Hats, with embroidery £4.10 each x 1000 = £4100
Scarves 85p x 1000 = £850
Transport, Petrol cost ect £250
Miscellaneous £160

When we DON'T reach our goal we will still use the money rasied to still buy hats and gloves and scarves as we still want to make sure we want the homeless to be warm this winter


Brixton Soup Kitchen doing outreach giving clothes and food to the homeless on the streets on London

story:
ABOUT THE FILM

When a lonely man begins getting anonymous erotic phones at work, he lets all other facets of his life fall away until he becomes convinced he must see the person on the other end of the line. Meeting that person becomes a regrettable journey into self-hatred, perversion, and tragic comedy.

Learn more about the story by watching this video:


/ / /

Smother Me In Hugs is a Columbia University graduate thesis film directed by Eric Schuman. Through the unique genre of dark comedy, Eric is exploring his insecurities and fears by delving into the experience of Garrett, an awkward, socially inept, middle-aged man who's settled for a mediocre life. 

The film tackles the themes of masculinity, confidence, and loneliness all through Garrett's eyes and, although very personal to the director, these themes are universal. Everyone understands what it's like to want something that seems out of reach, to be nervous around someone, or to feel out of place. And although we may not have gotten erotic phone calls on our work phone in the middle of the day, everyone understands what it's like to have a secret.

The film received the Emerging Filmmakers award from Columbia University and is currently a semi-finalist for the Screencraft Short Film Production Grant.

On the film's website, you can read the film's synopsis, peruse the director's statement, take a gander at the film's look book, and more.

 WHAT WE NEED

The film will be shot in New Jersey and New York City in early June of 2016, and all of the funds from this campaign will go towards the following elements of production: 

  • On-set Meals - Because filmmaking requires people, and people need to eat.
  • Casting - Finding the right actor for each of the three roles is a crucial part of making this film come to life, and this means hiring a New York City casting director and allowing for time to hold auditions, call-backs, and rehearsals.
  • Transportation - Imagine yourself on a New York City subway at 5 in the morning; you're carrying a camera, a tripod, lenses, lights, costumes, lunch for 15 people, and a couple of binders. That puddle of juice from the end of the subway car is making it's way towards your Trader Joe's bag, coming closer and closer with each acceleration of the train. Only 45 minutes to go.....Now imagine a passenger van with a spacious trunk, no juice on the ground, gliding along a pre-rush hour highway. I know, we like the second scenario better, too.
  • Location Fees - One of our locations is a parking lot, and in order to keep our cast and crew as safe as possible we must obtain permits to close down these areas. (We also will be purchasing reflective vests, both because they look really cool, and so we can keep our cast and crew visible and safe.) We'll also be trying filming at a frozen yogurt store and a deli, and may have to pay fees to use these locations as well.
  • Equipment - Although we will be using some of the equipment provided by Columbia University, we are also going to be renting from other equipment vendors for things like specific camera lenses and lights.
  • Our Cinematographer - Eric (the Director) and Ben (the Cinematographer) have been friends and collaborators for years, and will be a great team in the making of this film. However Ben lives in LA and we're shooting in the North East, and it might be a little tough for Ben to Skype onto set every day and shout camera directions from a fuzzy, frozen computer screen. In exchange for helping us out for free (!) we're going to fly Ben from LA for a few weeks so that he and Eric can work together on this film.
  • Editing - Editing goes beyond just putting the clips in the proper order; there's the (expensive) hard drives, making the rough cut, editing the audio and doing a color correction pass, all of which take time, and time is money. 
Every dollar helps us out! Below we've listed a few things that will be covered by your donations:


OUR TEAM

ERIC SCHUMAN (Director) 

Eric Schuman is a New York-based director, screenwriter, and cinematographer in his fourth year as an MFA Directing Candidate at Columbia University. He graduated with honors from Vassar College as a Film Major. When he was in eighth grade, he won the intellectual curiosity award from his school. This is his proudest achievement.



ANNAMARIE FERNANDEZ (Producer) 

Annamarie is an MFA Creative Producing concentrate at Columbia University. She graduated from Southern Methodist University in Dallas, TX with a degree in Film and Media Arts in 2013, and worked for two years as an Associate Producer for a Dallas-based production company producing commercials, promotional videos, and the Dallas Cowboy’s live-taped talk show, “Inside the Huddle.” Since starting school at Columbia she has acted as either Writer, Assistant Director, or Producer on a total of 12 films. Annamarie is interested in films that express personal truths, fears, and insecurities through comedy, and, as a producer, aims to support and encourage other artists seeking the same thing.

CARVER DISERENS (Co-Producer) 

Carver is currently an MFA Creative Producing concentrate at Columbia University. Carver has worked in film and television in New York City since 2009 working on various projects including, “The Colbert Report”, “How to Make it in America”, “Curb Your Enthusiasm”, “Men in Black III”, “Person of Interest”, "Anchorman II" and Amazon’s “Alpha House.” He has worked in accounting, production and locations departments. Originally from Westchester, New York, Carver has lived in Manhattan for the past five years. Carver is naturally drawn to comedy in all forms but finds it to be most effective when it strikes a deeper, meaningful statement or critique about our society.

Learn more about our two producers by watching this video:


Ben Rutkowski (Cinematographer) 

Ben is a Los Angeles-based cinematographer and an alumni of the NYU graduate film program. He has shot for clients such as Facebook, Red Bull, Sony, Air France, Salvatore Ferragamo, Maybelleine, GQ and the Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation. His cinematography has been recognized with award nominations from Kodak and ARRI, and appeared at Sundance, SXSW, TriBeCa, LA Film Festival, Cannes Lions, Austin Film Festival, Raindance, Hamptons International Film Festival, BAMCinemaFest and many more national and international festivals. As a director, his short film “Glory Days” was nominated for the Spike Lee Award in Filmmaking at the 2012 Starz Denver Film Festival along with screening at Slamdance, Woodstock and Sarasota Film Festivals.

TIM O’CONNOR (Assistant Director) 

Tim began his professional work in production on blockbuster films such as “Men in Black 3”, “The Dark Knight Rises” and “The Amazing Spider-Man 2”.  He has worked as 1st Assistant Director on over a dozen short films in the last five years. His writing/directing credits include the Reel 13 contest-winning short, “Jesus Talk”, which premiered on PBS. Tim is currently pursuing an MFA in Directing at Columbia University and won the Alfred P. Sloan Foundation Feature Treatment Competition for narrative films on scientific subjects.

JUDY BOWMAN (Casting Director)

Judy has been casting in New York City since 1993.  Recent film casting includes DWARVES OF DEMREL, HURRICANE BIANCA, LOST CAT CORONA, ELI MORAN, & GOLD STAR.  She received an Artios Award nomination for her casting of the webseries KARL MANHAIR: POSTAL INSPECTOR.  Casting on Broadway and off, she currently casts for the Mint Theater Company, Partial Comfort, Project Y, Woolly Mammoth Theater Co, Dorset Theatre Festival, TheatreSquared, Kitchen Theatre Company, & San Francisco Playhouse.  She is an adjunct Asst. Professor at Columbia University Film School's MFA program, and is a former faculty member at Harlem School of the Arts.


HOW ELSE CAN YOU HELP?

If you aren't able to contribute financially, we understand; although this film is important, sometimes feeding yourself and paying rent are just more of a priority. But there are still a few ways you can help us out:

  • Use the Indiegogo Share tool to help us get the word out about this film. The more people that see this page, the more help we get!
  • Follow us on Facebook and Twitter; we are all about those Likes and Retweets.
  • Share our promotional videos and project updates with your friends and family on social media (or in real life if you're into that sort of thing). Again, the more people that know about our film, the more support we get.

We are so grateful for all of your support - both financial and otherwise - and are really excited about making this film happen!

Thanks!

story:
Welcome to Night Creature Productions Indiegogo campaign!!

This is our first time using crowdsourcing to produce a project, and we have a story that we are sure is going to entertain our audience!!

I'm Christopher Ambriz and I'm a filmmaker and photojournalist based out of Corpus Christi, Texas.  I've been making films all my life and I love to tell a great story! Night Creature Productions is an award winning film production company and this will be our 11th film project.

We made a version of THE DATE last year for a film contest and I felt while making the film that we could do better with more money and time.  I think this is a really cool movie idea and I need help to get it off the ground.

If you contribute to this film, we will have a chance to have greater photography, better special make-up effects and a film we can travel around the film festival circuit!

We need funding for locations, special effects and camera gear.  The more funding we raise, the better the film will be!

Contributing $5 will get your name in the credits, $10 will give you a signed copy of the film when it's completed, $25 will get you an official crew t-shirt.

Your funds will go 100% into the creation of the film and we will make videos to update you on the progress of the film.

Your contribution to the film will allow Night Creature Productions to add another awesome film to our cannon of films.  We will give the horror fans something to watch and provide great entertainment, but only if we can reach our goal.  If we don't meet our goal, we'll try to match the rest out of pocket or scaleback the scope of the film if we have to.

Our films El Cucuy, Pen  and The Night Before have gotten great reviews and have traveled the festival circuit and are featured on YouTube and regularly watched!

I've worked in TV and film for over 15 years and I have the knowledge and background to get this film done no matter the budget or schedule.  I work on a daily basis of deadlines.

Help us make THE DATE an awesome experience!  So please contribute to our Indiegogo campaign and make this a successful project that you can show your friends and family!! 

Thanks, 

Christopher Ambriz

story:
Welcome to The Soul Whisperer Project:   A documentary film and a 20 city North American 2016 seven month healing tour.  The above video you just saw is the opening sequence we created after our six week, seven city tour last spring and it leads to several other short clips from the film.  That is what this campaign is all about, to complete this inspiring documentary.

We captured some very powerful footage of peoples' struggles, pain and trauma, all of which are held in the body.  We are living in a world where pain and discomfort are numbed out, moved away from or dare I say, demonized.  I am calling it the "Numbification" of America.   We are in an epidemic when over 100 million Americans are prescribed some sort of pharmaceutical drug for pain, anxiety and depression.

Feelings buried alive never die.  There are archetypal patterns in the emotional/psychological holdings in the body for every person.  Mark says, "I assist people in identifying, feeling and consciously experiencing their pain." Most people spend a lot of their energy avoiding pain and discomfort causing a contractive state which actually perpetuates and intensifies the pain.  Pain is a language and must be decoded, translated and understood, Mark goes on to say, "Sometimes the only way through pain...is through pain." Feeling the pain and honoring it creates the heat that transmutes the unconscious dross into energy that can be used to manifest a more meaningful, purposeful and soulful life. 

Our goal is to reach as many people as we can through private Transformational Bodywork sessions and group workshops called The Anatomy of Emotion.  This was my main inspiration with creating this documentary, to reach, educate and raise awareness about this issue and the healing power of Transformational Bodywork. 

Our first campaign we did last spring raised almost $1,800.00.  This was amazing and thank you to everyone who donated then.  This basically paid for our gas on the first road trip.  Everything I made on that last tour I pumped right back into the project, hence why we are doing another fundraising campaign.  

All funds raised go directly into the project which include:

*All pre and post production editing and filming, this is where a majority of the    funds will go.  This is the most time consuming and the meat of the project.

*Equipment both bought and rented:  Cameras, mics, hard drives, lighting, etc...

*Gas and transportation.

*Non-hosted Accommodations on the road trip.

These are just a few of the crucial areas the funds will be used for.  Thank you so much for your support and love to make this vision/dream a reality.

Follow us on the journey through all the social media tools we are using to share the adventures with you.  The links are below.

Here is the list of the participating cities for the 2016 Soul Whisperer Tour:

Santa Cruz, CA.,  Feb. 5-10th   @  Pleasure Point Yoga

San Diego, CA.,  Feb. 19-25   @   TBA 

Albuquerque, NM.,    Mar. 10-17   @  Sweat Yoga

Santa Fe, NM.,   Mar. 18-24   @   Uplifted Fitness

Dallas, TX.,   Mar. 30-Apr. 7   @   UpTown Yoga

Panama City, FL.,  Apr. 18-28   @  Balance Health Studio

Atlanta, GA.,   Apr. 29-May 5    @   TBA

Washington D.C.,  May 14-16   @  TBA 

New Jersey,  May 24-30   @   TBA

Ottawa, Canada,  Jun. 3-9   @  TBA

Fort Wayne, IN.,   Jun. 10-15   @  TBA

Madison, WI.,  Jun. 17-22   @   TBA 

Minneapolis, MN.,  Jun. 22-July 1   @  TBA

Denver, CO.,  July 7-14   @   Core Power Yoga

Vancouver, Canada,   July 27-Aug. 3   @  TBA

Seattle, WA.,   Aug. 9-13   @  TBA

Portland, Oregon.,   Aug. 14-18    @  TBA


Dates and Locations will be updated on the beyondbodywork.com website.


Wishing you a Wonderful New Year

Lovingly

Mark and the BeyondBodywork Team
story_txt: Welcome to The Soul Whisperer Project:   A documentary film and a 20 city North American 2016 seven month healing tour.  The above video you just saw is the opening sequence we created after our six week, seven city tour last spring and it leads to several other short clips from the film.  That is what this campaign is all about, to complete this inspiring documentary.We captured some very powerful footage of peoples' struggles, pain and trauma, all of which are held in the body.  We are living in a world where pain and discomfort are numbed out, moved away from or dare I say, demonized.  I am calling it the "Numbification" of America.   We are in an epidemic when over 100 million Americans are prescribed some sort of pharmaceutical drug for pain, anxiety and depression.Feelings buried alive never die.  There are archetypal patterns in the emotional/psychological holdings in the body for every person.  Mark says, "I assist people in identifying, feeling and consciously experiencing their pain." Most people spend a lot of their energy avoiding pain and discomfort causing a contractive state which actually perpetuates and intensifies the pain.  Pain is a language and must be decoded, translated and understood, Mark goes on to say, "Sometimes the only way through pain...is through pain." Feeling the pain and honoring it creates the heat that transmutes the unconscious dross into energy that can be used to manifest a more meaningful, purposeful and soulful life. Our goal is to reach as many people as we can through private Transformational Bodywork sessions and group workshops called The Anatomy of Emotion.  This was my main inspiration with creating this documentary, to reach, educate and raise awareness about this issue and the healing power of Transformational Bodywork. Our first campaign we did last spring raised almost $1,800.00.  This was amazing and thank you to everyone who donated then.  This basically paid for our gas on the first road trip.  Everything I made on that last tour I pumped right back into the project, hence why we are doing another fundraising campaign.  All funds raised go directly into the project which include:*All pre and post production editing and filming, this is where a majority of the    funds will go.  This is the most time consuming and the meat of the project.*Equipment both bought and rented:  Cameras, mics, hard drives, lighting, etc...*Gas and transportation.*Non-hosted Accommodations on the road trip.These are just a few of the crucial areas the funds will be used for.  Thank you so much for your support and love to make this vision/dream a reality.Follow us on the journey through all the social media tools we are using to share the adventures with you.  The links are below.Here is the list of the participating cities for the 2016 Soul Whisperer Tour:Santa Cruz, CA.,  Feb. 5-10th   @  Pleasure Point YogaSan Diego, CA.,  Feb. 19-25   @   TBA Albuquerque, NM.,    Mar. 10-17   @  Sweat YogaSanta Fe, NM.,   Mar. 18-24   @   Uplifted FitnessDallas, TX.,   Mar. 30-Apr. 7   @   UpTown YogaPanama City, FL.,  Apr. 18-28   @  Balance Health StudioAtlanta, GA.,   Apr. 29-May 5    @   TBAWashington D.C.,  May 14-16   @  TBA New Jersey,  May 24-30   @   TBAOttawa, Canada,  Jun. 3-9   @  TBAFort Wayne, IN.,   Jun. 10-15   @  TBAMadison, WI.,  Jun. 17-22   @   TBA Minneapolis, MN.,  Jun. 22-July 1   @  TBADenver, CO.,  July 7-14   @   Core Power YogaVancouver, Canada,   July 27-Aug. 3   @  TBASeattle, WA.,   Aug. 9-13   @  TBAPortland, Oregon.,   Aug. 14-18    @  TBADates and Locations will be updated on the beyondbodywork.com website.Wishing you a Wonderful New YearLovinglyMark and the BeyondBodywork Team

Short Summary

Chase Street is a political-crime Television drama set in Camden, New Jersey that is starring and directed by veteran actor Clifton Powell. Currently in the post-production faze, the project is seeking funds to help finish editing and to market and promote the pilot episode. With the right amount of promotion we are confident, Chase Street will catch the attention of a network. Thanks for your support!

story:
Short Summary

“Great Highway” is in the later stages of post production.   Our final hurdle is to pay for licensing.  This money pays the people, libraries, and companies who provided us with archival imagery and footage.  That is what this campaign is all about.  We must cover all of these costs to avoid legal action for using something without proper permission.  This is the last, but very vital, step in a long journey of telling the history of San Francisco surfing.

Your contributions will make it possible for us to bring this remarkable story to the public for the first time.  More people than ever are surfing, and the team that created “Great Highway” feels an obligation to let people know how surfing in San Francisco evolved and grew into what it is today.


What We Need & What You Get

Here is a list of what we still need to take care of in order to tell this
amazing story.  Use of the song “Green Eyed Lady” is important because
it’s actually part of the story:

•  $5,200 – San Francisco Public Library for use of archival images,
microfilm, and articles
•  $3,000 – To retain an entertainment lawyer
•  $5,000 – MPL music publishing for the use of the song “Green Eyed Lady.”
•  $1,800 – Graphic design; digitization and duplication; film festival fees

For anyone who contributes $500, they will receive an "Associate Producer"
title in the credits of the film.  For a $1,000 or higher contribution
that person would receive an "Executive Producer" title in the credits.

The Impact

You donation will help preserve the rich history of San Francisco and the culture of surfing in the Northern California region.  San Francisco was never considered
a "surf town" even though people have been surfing here longer than the
Giants or the 49er's or the Warriors have been in town.  That's the story
you will help to bring to the public as a contributor.  It is a contribution toward
educating people about the beach lifestyle in northern California and
about the mystical connection we have to the ocean here and elsewhere in the world.  It's also about the connections many surfers here have with people and places  in Hawaii, the center of the surfing world.  This is a story that no one has told because people never paid much attention to what was going on with regard to surfing here. 

I've previously produced and directed a surf video in 2004 titled "NorCal
Project" that was a big hit in our local area.  As Technical Director for
the Interactive Media Festival in 1995, I was in charge of 30 interactive
installations that included AI, robotics, and Virtual Reality spanning 4
floors in the Variety Arts Center in Los Angeles.  The festival ran it's
course without any failures of any kind and a very successful event


Risks & Challenges

Most of the challenges we have faced have been met already, as we are done
with the production of the film.  The hurdle now is to raise this last bit
of money needed for licensing fees.  Everything else with regard to "Great Highway" is in place.

Our plan is to work hard to meet our goals on this site and get the word
out as far and wide as possible using social media, email, and phone calls
to everyone we know interested in our project.

story:
Polterguys is an unusual story about life, death and everything in between.

Best friends Jim and Daniel can't seem to get over the death of their flatmate, Antony. So, after an alcohol fueled evening of paranormal activity, they awake to find the ghost of their friend 'alive' and well. 
Now they need to help Antony die (again) so he can finally rest in peace. However, it's not as easy as they thought. It's not as if Ouija boards have instructions.

What We Need & What You Get

Polterguys isn't an extremely high budget project. Nonetheless, it does require a lot of time, effort and comically large props. Which is where you come in!

With each donation, you are helping our team of hard working and witty people make this series to, in the end, entertain you. Every click, every share, every bit of money you can give will help to pay for our props, locations and actors time to make Polterguys bigger and better!


The Sad News

Here, we all understand that sometimes things don't always happen the way we expect it to. That is why, every single bit of your donations will go towards making this series. Even if we don't reach our main goal, we will use what we have be given to create something entertaining and funny to raise your spirits.


Other Ways You Can Help

If you don't have any money, we totally get it... neither do we. But you can still help! Here are other ways to show us some love:

  • Spread the word and share the campaign video with everyone you know, alive or dead!
  • Say hello and like us on Facebook and Twitter. Or, give us a follow on Youtube to see how the series is going.

story:
We're Casting!

We've currently reached the casting stage of preproduction and last week were happy to cast Niall Coyle who will be playing the role of Tony in the present day narrative of Come Visit. Have a look at his eloquently exposed ideas on agism, sex and personal growth.

Thank You!

Thanks to all our backers who have helped us raise fund for the project so far. This little celebration video is for you!



Short Summary

Come Visit is a student film project lead by students of the MA Filmmaking course at Goldsmiths College, University of London. We're a group of talented and dedicated film students with extensive background in film production.

Come Visit is a short drama film which explores the nature of friendship, companionship and intimacy within the context of the porn industry. The project will explore a unique relationship which is formed in the UK's 70s porn industry and then reunited in the present day, to reveal to the audience that there's more to porn than one would think... 

The film will allow the audience to explore the UK's 70s porn scene and the more clinical environment of the hospital room, in which protagonists Freckles and Tony reunite to consider the start of their friendship. He made her feel good once, and now she can return the favour.

What We Need & What You Get

The funds we acquire from this campaign will support us in making Come Visit the best that it can be! We require these funds to book locations, hire equipment and pay our cast and dress our sets, so that we can recreate the unique setting and atmosphere of the 70s porn industry. Help us bring to life a touching friendship story within the salacious world of porn!

Should we not reach our targets our funds will continue to go into the production, but it won't look as good. So make sure you help make Come Visit the best that it can be!

Other Ways You Can Help

If you think you have something to contribute to this project, we'd love to hear from you. Please visit us online at www.comevisitfilm.com to see production updates and to get in touch.

story:
Short Summary

 

 

I am Ian Sweet and have been working in the television broadcast industry for over thirty years as a commentator, camera man, editor, producer and director. My passion is sport along with music. When I moved to the Mad River Valley in Vermont in 2002 I soon discovered that music plays a vital role within the whole community. Since I have always wanted to make a music documentary, the music and musicians in the Valley give me that opportunity.

I have wondered why the Mad River Valley is full of musicians and hosts such a diverse cross section of  music. I need to find out why!

By supporting this project you will meet a wide range of musicians, their teachers and inspirations along with finding out why these people call the Mad River Valley home.

 

What We Need & What You Get

 

Producing a documentary requires passion, support and finance. I need your support to raise the $27500K to fund this project. This is a low budget documentary, but money is needed for equipment (although I personally own a great deal which will be used on the project), travel costs to interview several top musicians who have left the Valley to pursue their musical careers, music copyright licensing, duplication, printing costs, and finally promotion of the documentary Mad Music.

Whilst supporting the project I will be keep you up to date on the progress. On completition of the documetary you will be invited to the local airing of Mad Music here in the Mad River Valley.

Even if all the funds are not raised, rest assured that I will complete this documentary to the best of my ability.

 

    The Impact

     

    Despite the fact that the Mad River Valley, like most of Vermont, is a tough place to live, Mad Music will show that it is always possible to follow your musical dreams.

    My passion has enabled me to cover numerous Olympic Games allowing me to meet the best of the best. Living here in the Mad River Valley has made me realize that the musicians here are also living their dream and yes, most will never be recognized outside the Valley, but their love of the Valley and music will live on.

    Mad Music aims to discover why musicians come here, stay and make music, and in some case move on to greatness.

     

      Risks & Challenges

       

      The question why may never be fully answered, however Mad Music will show the journey that all musicians make when trying to fulfill their dreams.

        Other Ways You Can Help

         

        These are tough times and you may not be able to help finance this project. However, you can always spread the word about Mad Music to friends, family and co-workers. Show your support in any way possible.  Please promote on social media and through the Indiegogo share tools.

        MY TEAM

        I will be directing and shooting most of the material. Our associate producer is Rob Williams, a local musician who fully understands and has extensive knowledge of the Valley music. Rob will be undertaking interviews and providing a voice when required. Eric Sigsby who co-owns Sugarhouse Soundworks, has come on board as executive producer through his  other company Laughing Eagle Productions. Roger Stauss, the other co-owner of Sugarhouse Soundworks, will be assisting with the final audio mix. Sugarhouse Soundworks will also be assisting with equipment necessary for the documentary.

story:
Hey guys,

my name is Dragosh, I live in Moldova, Republic of, and I'm 21.
What's so special about me? Absolutely nothing, except the fact that I want badly to be a TV Show Producer. 
I can't go to TV channels here because besides our country is devides by oligarhs, the media is almost the least independent structure in here.
If you don't believe me: Google something about Moldova and a stolen billion dollars. :)) This means that people who work in the media are their relatives and friends - and I'm not one of them. 
That's why I'm asking for your help!
 



I already took the matter into my own hands and started a Youtube channel with a couple of TV Shows.

I'm trying to realize all my ideas for shows, but for now, the technical equiment (which I rent) doesn't reach my ideas. ((
Too bad, because I'm young, and I'm full of ideas about this video production thing, and I'm really sorry that money is the only thing that doesn't allow me realize it, and I hope that you will help me!

With the money I'll manage to earn here, I'll buy all the equiment I need: 
A camera of course: I'm thinking a DSLR (cheaper) T3i or T5i. Or a real camcorder, if the campain goes well :))
A PC for graphics and editing, different stands, tripods, sliders, storage and other video gear.

I would be super-gratefull if you'd help a 21 guy realize his dreams in an post-soviet country!

story:
Help us make this feature film...

We have used £1000 of our own money to produce a short Proof Of Concept film over the summer of 2016 and now wish to move on and make the full feature length film.  We have a committed team who want to make this great story into a great film, take a look at what we achieved with £1000 and you will see that with our target amount we can make a great film. 

We showed the short to lots of people now and a few of their observations are below...

Comments So Far

" I enjoyed it. He he did a great job for £1000, these things aren't easy, give the makers my congrats and good luck."   Phil Davis (Actor: Whitechapel, Poldark, Quadrophenia)

 

The Long Way Home short is a stunning piece of film. With a solid heart-rending story, it is packed full of great powerful and moving acting, together with stunning authentic costume and locations Simon Golding (Novelist, Scriptwriter, Producer)

 

"This is the kind of film I would like to sit down to watch on Boxing Day afternoon"

"It reminds me of Downton Abbey"

"I didn't want it to end, I wanted to know what happened to Captain Hemmingway"

"I would pay to see just this short film at the cinema"

 

So what is it all about?

With the approach of the 100th anniversary of the end of The Great War I was compelled to write a film about the experiences of "Pals Battalions", made up of volunteers from the Stately Homes, villages and workforces from factories. As the war comes to an end Captain John Hemmingway must decide between following orders or protecting the men under his command.

Our small team have been working on this project for over a year, from the original idea formed a few years ago we first wrote the short script and then began using that as a basis for the longer version. Bringing on board Ben Seager who plays Captain Hemmingway as lead and Mat Hammond as cinematographer gave us the opportunity to move on with the project and produce a Proof Of Concept film over the summer of 2016.

Take a look at it now.

 

To watch this in full screen visit our Vimeo page and watch it there... https://vimeo.com/181718602

Jake (Director)

 

Where Do We Go From Here

Our campaign is to allow us to produce the full feature length version of the film. As someone Shropshire born I wanted the story to revolve around the county and its men who went off to the war, an earlier project I worked on with the British Film Institute centred on Prees Heath, a training centre for soldiers and later a military hospital and I felt that it was important to continue their story to the trenches of Belgium.

We shot a short 15 minute version of the film this summer on less than £1000, most of which was spent on hiring a uniform for our lead actor (if you know anyone with a WW1 officers uniform then please put them in touch, they are hellishly expensive). The whole team pulled together, taking days off work and staying in the directors home so that they could all travel together and save costs, demonstrating a belief in the project and our ability to create a great film from the script. The costs of such a film can be huge, we don't want to make a film relying on special effects and hundreds of extras though some of these will inevitably be necessary, our film is a more personal journey following one officer and workers from his estate who join up with him.

 

Risks & Challenges

For us the most important thing is to ensure that this film is historically correct, we have a number of military advisors involved including re-enactors who specialise in this period and also Graham Jones, author of the book 'The Apley Legions' the story of the pals who joined up from The Apley Estate near Bridgnorth. 

Where The Money Goes

We are seeking £16,000 to make this film. This is a project trimmed to the bone with as much as possible borrowed and begged from anywhere we can. This (very) small sum in film terms allows us to make a great film, if we get more then we can make it even better. The chart below shows how the money would be distributed.

The biggest expenditure in a film of this type is on locations and costume, one officers uniform for our test shoot this summer cost £600 to hire for a week. For the final film we will need more for longer and the cost will rocket up, of course depending on how much we raise we will cut our cloth accordingly, so a smaller budget will mean fewer officers and a smaller cast all round. Locations are vital to this, we can make a trench look amazing but car noise nearby will ruin the effect, so would an airplane flying over. It is the detail like this and the time it takes to check and double check that ramps up the costs.

Sound is perhaps the most important part of a film, we have all noticed how music can affect a scene but it is the details of the ambient sound too that make a great shot. We need to employ a professional sound recordist, to ensure that the sound is perfect.

While sound is a vital part of the finished film, food is THE vital part of the shoot on set, especially when you are asking your cast to trudge through mud and rain for hours at a time, and then do it again for another take. Coffee to warm people up, water to cool them down and plenty to food to sustain them are vital, we treat everyone on set the way we would want to be treated with a dedicated team to ensure regular supplies.

 

How WE reward YOU

We want investors to feel involved in the project, so we thought long and hard about experiences and opportunities to offer as perks. We have tried to ensure that everyone feels part of the team and so every investor will receive access to a special page on the website where we will provide updates on the film, excerpts from Captain Hemmingway's diary and news of special events amongst other things.

Our range of experience perks are second to none, we start these at a low level of investment and will make these great for all involved. They revolve primarily around involvement in the filming process or the launch of the completed film, we want everyone to feel special and valued.  

Of course you can support us with a contribution without a perk...just click "Back It" to the right of the page above the perks section. Whatever you decide, please don't forget to share this page with your friends and anyone that you know would be interested, film buffs, history fanatics etc.

What Happens If We Don't Make Our Target

This film is going to be made come what may, we are passionate about the project and WILL SEE IT THROUGH. If we don't reach our goal then we will put every single penny received into making the BEST film we can, just the length and complexity of the story will change.

This is why we chose flexible funding, we know that to persuade strangers to feel trust a young team with their money isn't easy, we know that people are concerned that if the target isn't reached we will just pocket the money ad say "Oh well, we tried, lets go to the pub" (none of us drink by the way!). Let me re-iterate, however much we receive at the end of the campaign, every single penny, cent, rupee, washer or piece of Monopoly money will be used to make the best film we are able to on the money we have.

We are not just sitting back and waiting for the money to come in, we are trying everything we can think of too, vintage clothes sales, concerts, a raffle...you name it we are trying it - to raise the money ourselves. 

See our Proof Of Concept film below to see what we were able to do with less than £1000,  

The Impact

This is a story that we passionately believe in, that we think everyone should see and with the 100 year anniversary of the Armistice approaching this is the perfect time to tell it. There are no survivors of the fighting left now and soon there will be no one left alive who lived through the war at home; It is important to tell their stories, to reflect the huge sacrifices and great toll the war took, often unnecessarily. We plan to offer an educational cut to schools to teach about this time and what ordinary people went through, not a glamorous experience but a dirty, smelly terrifying one...

 

Meet The Team

Jake- Director

Jake began his professional career as a child actor in the touring production of Disney’s Beauty and the Beast with UK Productions where he played Chip the teacup.  He went on to perform in Fiddler on the Roof, Joseph, Dr Doolittle and many others before turning his mind to music where he spent a couple of years as guitarist in a band, eventually signing to a record label and making 2 music videos before the band unfortunately stalled. He is still a keen guitarist playing at university with colleagues and amongst friends.

Due to a Saturday job working with the Pauline Quirke Academy in Bridgnorth he became interested in film and film making. His first project ‘The Watcher’ received a premier at the Bridgnorth Majestic Cinema before an audience of over 200.  His first  short film 'A Bench On Platform 3' was around 7 minutes long and shot on the platform of the Severn Valley Railway before moving on to 'Droplets' a short psychological film about a hired assassin coming face to face with her nemesis only to realise that she had hired him herself. 

Jake is the youngest person ever to qualify to teach the Shakespeare Awards with the world famous Royal Academy of Dramatic Art.  His acting experience and teaching training makes him an ‘actors director’ working with the cast on their performance as well as overseeing the whole production.

 

Mat Hammond - Cinematographer

Born and raised in the Black Country, Mathew Hammond is an experienced screenwriter and short film director and producer. For almost a decade he has been honing his skills and understanding of the craft through his work on fiction and non-fiction short films, as well as commercial material. Since 2012 he has been running a commercial video production business, and working independently on productions across the nation.

Having graduated with a degree in Film Production from the University of Central Lancashire in 2013, in recent years, the ambitious filmmaker has collected a wealth of different experiences in the field of teaching film. His background ranges from that of directing a wide variety of performers both young and adult, to running workshops with child and adult actors. He has been involved in large scale feature length films, and worked as a camera operator on popular events, like music concerts for chart topping artists.

Mathew is a strong believer in the education of young and driven filmmakers, particularly when it comes to the principals of filmmaking. Along with the rest of the team he is keen to share his knowledge.

Ben Seager Captain Hemmingway

Ben graduated from Manchester Metropolitan School of Theatre with an Honours Degree in Acting. During his time at University, he not only pursued his passion for acting but also developed a keen interest in directing and writing.

During his final year at University, Ben was selected to direct a live action piece of drama at Castlefields Art Gallery, where the exhibits were used as a backdrop for a performance of David Osbaldeston's "Out of Time"

With his "Director's Hat" firmly in place, Ben then went on to devise, direct and write an original piece of work "Held by the Habit" for his dissertation. This one-act play was then submitted to a new writers' competition and was subsequently selected to be performed at a London Theatre.

Since graduating, Ben has worked as a Film and Media Assistant and Youth support worker at a sixth form college and, more recently, has been assisting and directing A level students in preparation for their university auditions. He also has experience of supporting students who are working towards their LAMDA speech examinations and has delivered drama workshops to children from the ages of 5-16 years. Ben particularly enjoyed writing a short piece which was performed by these students at their Christmas production, thereby revealing his talent for writing comedy!

Ben has continued his interest in all things creative and during the last year has written a script for a short film, composed a number of songs (lyrics and melodies  which he loves to sing!) and has also written a short story for a Classical Greek Dance piece which won first place at the National Classical Greek Dance Festival.

Josh Griffiths

I am Joshua Griffiths I am 18 years old, I have wanted to be an actor most of my life, drawn to  their work on screen. I have appeared in a few college productions where I played a character, in a show called Hello based on the book of mormon. Then I was a 'scavenger' in the dance show called base 21, then lastly I was in the college showcase of When I grow up based on the Matilda Musical where I played Rudulpho. I have also been on the West End stage in Her Majesty's Theatre with my performing arts school,

Recently I starred in a short educational film which will tour around schools in the uk teaching people about extremism. In my spare time I love writing stories, poems, songs and also scripts. I also write film with friends and experiment with ways of shooting scenes to learn more about the craft of film making.

 

Other Important Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:

If you have got this far then this is a project that you, at the very least, find interesting - or you know someone who might. Please take a little time to share our page with others, link to our Facebook page @thelongwayhomefilm or even our Twitter @tlwhfilm... We will love you for it.
story_txt:
Help us make this feature film...
We have used £1000 of our own money to produce a short Proof Of Concept film over the summer of 2016 and now wish to move on and make the full feature length film.  We have a committed team who want to make this great story into a great film, take a look at what we achieved with £1000 and you will see that with our target amount we can make a great film. 
We showed the short to lots of people now and a few of their observations are below...
Comments So Far
" I enjoyed it. He he did a great job for £1000, these things aren't easy, give the makers my congrats and good luck."   Phil Davis (Actor: Whitechapel, Poldark, Quadrophenia)
 
The Long Way Home short is a stunning piece of film. With a solid heart-rending story, it is packed full of great powerful and moving acting, together with stunning authentic costume and locations Simon Golding (Novelist, Scriptwriter, Producer)
 
"This is the kind of film I would like to sit down to watch on Boxing Day afternoon"
"It reminds me of Downton Abbey"
"I didn't want it to end, I wanted to know what happened to Captain Hemmingway"
"I would pay to see just this short film at the cinema"
 
So what is it all about?
With the approach of the 100th anniversary of the end of The Great War I was compelled to write a film about the experiences of "Pals Battalions", made up of volunteers from the Stately Homes, villages and workforces from factories. As the war comes to an end Captain John Hemmingway must decide between following orders or protecting the men under his command.
Our small team have been working on this project for over a year, from the original idea formed a few years ago we first wrote the short script and then began using that as a basis for the longer version. Bringing on board Ben Seager who plays Captain Hemmingway as lead and Mat Hammond as cinematographer gave us the opportunity to move on with the project and produce a Proof Of Concept film over the summer of 2016.
Take a look at it now.


 
To watch this in full screen visit our Vimeo page and watch it there... https://vimeo.com/181718602
Jake (Director)

 
Where Do We Go From Here
Our campaign is to allow us to produce the full feature length version of the film. As someone Shropshire born I wanted the story to revolve around the county and its men who went off to the war, an earlier project I worked on with the British Film Institute centred on Prees Heath, a training centre for soldiers and later a military hospital and I felt that it was important to continue their story to the trenches of Belgium.
We shot a short 15 minute version of the film this summer on less than £1000, most of which was spent on hiring a uniform for our lead actor (if you know anyone with a WW1 officers uniform then please put them in touch, they are hellishly expensive). The whole team pulled together, taking days off work and staying in the directors home so that they could all travel together and save costs, demonstrating a belief in the project and our ability to create a great film from the script. The costs of such a film can be huge, we don't want to make a film relying on special effects and hundreds of extras though some of these will inevitably be necessary, our film is a more personal journey following one officer and workers from his estate who join up with him.
 

Risks & Challenges
For us the most important thing is to ensure that this film is historically correct, we have a number of military advisors involved including re-enactors who specialise in this period and also Graham Jones, author of the book 'The Apley Legions' the story of the pals who joined up from The Apley Estate near Bridgnorth. 


Where The Money Goes
We are seeking £16,000 to make this film. This is a project trimmed to the bone with as much as possible borrowed and begged from anywhere we can. This (very) small sum in film terms allows us to make a great film, if we get more then we can make it even better. The chart below shows how the money would be distributed.

The biggest expenditure in a film of this type is on locations and costume, one officers uniform for our test shoot this summer cost £600 to hire for a week. For the final film we will need more for longer and the cost will rocket up, of course depending on how much we raise we will cut our cloth accordingly, so a smaller budget will mean fewer officers and a smaller cast all round. Locations are vital to this, we can make a trench look amazing but car noise nearby will ruin the effect, so would an airplane flying over. It is the detail like this and the time it takes to check and double check that ramps up the costs.
Sound is perhaps the most important part of a film, we have all noticed how music can affect a scene but it is the details of the ambient sound too that make a great shot. We need to employ a professional sound recordist, to ensure that the sound is perfect.
While sound is a vital part of the finished film, food is THE vital part of the shoot on set, especially when you are asking your cast to trudge through mud and rain for hours at a time, and then do it again for another take. Coffee to warm people up, water to cool them down and plenty to food to sustain them are vital, we treat everyone on set the way we would want to be treated with a dedicated team to ensure regular supplies.
 
How WE reward YOU
We want investors to feel involved in the project, so we thought long and hard about experiences and opportunities to offer as perks. We have tried to ensure that everyone feels part of the team and so every investor will receive access to a special page on the website where we will provide updates on the film, excerpts from Captain Hemmingway's diary and news of special events amongst other things.
Our range of experience perks are second to none, we start these at a low level of investment and will make these great for all involved. They revolve primarily around involvement in the filming process or the launch of the completed film, we want everyone to feel special and valued.  
Of course you can support us with a contribution without a perk...just click "Back It" to the right of the page above the perks section. Whatever you decide, please don't forget to share this page with your friends and anyone that you know would be interested, film buffs, history fanatics etc.

Let me re-iterate, however much we receive at the end of the campaign, every single penny, cent, rupee, washer or piece of Monopoly money will be used to make the best film we are able to on the money we have.

story:
Story

  • When Kadie is invited to her best friend's sweet 16 party (where her crush will coincidentally be as well), she doesn't have the guts to ask her mother if she can go. Instead, she hatches a risky plan to sneak out and embarks on wild journey to find out what really matters to her.

Who I Am

  • Hailing from Kingston, Jamaica by way of Boston, MA (or maybe the other way around), I am a rising filmmaker ready to take on the world. I am finishing up my 3rd year of grad school in the Production program and would love to start producing more stories with a Caribbean influence as soon as possible! My dream is to highlight countries like Jamaica and showcase their rich culture to the world. Every donation here goes toward that dream!

      What We Need & What You Get

      • All the funds from this campaign are going towards the costs of this thesis film!
      • When you donate, please choose a tier on the right! These are unique perks I've thought carefully about and want to give something back for your donation! They've got a Jamaican flair, so don't miss your chance to score some exclusive souvenirs!
      • We need help with:

      Impact:

      • I wouldn't be able to tell stories like this if I didn't have people like you supporting me!
      • I believe representation of diverse cultures and people in the media is essential and I've always made a concerted effort to have a cast and crew that embodies that concept. 
      • If you support this campaign today, you'll be supporting responsible filmmaking and helping an awesome story get produced!

Hailing from Kingston, Jamaica by way of Boston, MA (or maybe the other way around), I am a rising filmmaker ready to take on the world. I am finishing up my 3rd year of grad school in the Production program and would love to start producing more stories with a Caribbean influence as soon as possible! We need help with:







Impact:

I wouldn't be able to tell stories like this if I didn't have people like you supporting me!
I believe representation of diverse cultures and people in the media is essential and I've always made a concerted effort to have a cast and crew that embodies that concept. 
If you support this campaign today, you'll be supporting responsible filmmaking and helping an awesome story get produced!

story:
About This Project

 

$10,000 were raised outside of this page for this student project.
story_txt: About This Project $10,000 were raised outside of this page for this student project.

story:
Our Film

Our short film NO ONE ELSE WILL was written and directed by Paul d'Indy. The idea behind this film has been in the process of being developed over the last five years. It first started as a historical fiction novel about the diary entries of a man who was conscripted into the Vietnam War. Then a few years later it was converted into a short story about a young girl who discovers her father's War diary and learns about him through his own voice. It was then finally developed into a short film script, which we are now developing into a short film. 

This story takes place in a small rural town in Australia, where nothing much happens. It is told from the perspective of the protagonist Kelly (16) and it is about her discovery of her absent fathers diary. It addresses key issues associated with the Vietnam War, such as PTSD, family issues, single parents and acting out youths. Kelly who has grown up with out a father or knowledge of a father has finally decided to seek out to truth. She decided to sneak out of her house one night after her mother has gone to bed, and explore her dad's old shed. But what she finds in there is not at all what she expected or could of imagined. 

This is a very ambitious project, we have a very passionate and talented team of people working very hard to create a stunning work of art. We wanted to challenge our self's to do something that was out there and not the normal standard for short films. Plus did I mention we are shooting on 35mm and 16mm film. We have partnered up with Panavision Asia to create this film, and they have been very supportive and excited that people like us still want to shoot on film. They have supplied us with our 35mm camera and lenses, so we are best equipped to make our film. 

RISK/Challengers

There are many risks and challenges associated with our film, but none that can't be over come with a little help. Because we have decided to shoot on film there comes there own set of challengers. 

Costs for us, is a major challenge we have to overcome, cost of film stock, developing, telecine and a lot more. It is all our dreams as filmmakers shoot on film once, for the experience and learning abilities. At the moment we are shooting at a ratio of 2:1!! Which our screen teacher thinks is absolutely crazy! But we need your help with funds to purchase more film stock to increase this ratio to something a little more feasible.

We also have the costs of locations, props, costumes ETC..  As this is a period piece there is a lot of production design work to be done. Fortunately for us we have two amazing production designers working day and night at it, but even they need help to buy resources. We would love your help to make sure that our dreams come true and to make the best film we can make. We only have two weeks left before we start shooting so PLEASE HELP US!!

How The Funds Will Be Used

The major cost in our project comes from shooting on film in both pre and post production, but there will also be hidden cost on both sides that we haven’t encountered yet. We will use our production funding on…

Film Stock $500

We’re excited to be shooting on film but it can be very expensive to purchase and develop stock in Australia as unfortunately us 35mm film shooters are a dying bread and there are not many people that can accommodate us.

Developing/Processing/Digitalizing $500

Once we have shot we have to send the exposed film away to be processed and converted to a digital hard drive so we can start editing it.

Production Design $1000

We are excited to shoot a period piece but with period pieces come big costs. The costs of costumes, renting a car from the 80’s, and designing a whole house in 80's style.

These are the three main cost we are struggling with a bit at the moment but we will over come them. If you have any questions at all don't hesitate to message me via email or facebook and I will try to answer you as soon as possible. Even if you cannot support the project finically there are other ways to support us, like sharing our crowd funding online with your friends, liking our page or donation any props or location you think are appropriate to our film as well as film stock.

I have been working in the film industry for the past two year, working on various different projects in both London and Sydney. Check out my Director Of Photography showreel below.

story:
Synopsis

When Kelly moves to London from Grimsby to start a new job, she comes prepared for the Northern jibes and sniggering puns.  Taking on a secret identity she seeks to rid London of those who poke fun and bully her leaving a very personal stamp on those who cross her.

Grimsby Girl is a dark, humorous and feel good film where the bad guys get their comeuppance and the good girls kick ass!

The Team

Niya Hill - Writer

Niya is an actress and writer based in London originally from Grimsby. She has worked in theatre, short films and commercials and stays healthy by practising and teaching yoga. Her favourite roles to date have been Arkadina in The Seagull at The Cockpit and Sasha in Coming&Going at the Bush theatre, directed by Rikki Beadle-Blair. She has recently formed her own production company producing and acting in short films. Grimsby Girl is her first short film as a writer.

Anna Keel - Director

Anna Keel is a BBC and Raindance Film School trained director known for a number of acclaimed documentaries before a later branch sideways into the world of drama. Her first short fiction film Seven Stones received special selection at a number of international festivals and her second, Lost Girl, earned her a best director nomination at The Southampton International Film Festival. Her first feature film – a British road movie thriller – is now in the pipeline. In between dreaming up drama Anna continues to make hard hitting, globally successful docs for The BBC, Channel 4, ITV  and more.

ASC - The Producers

The Actors Screen Collective are an autonomous group of highly skilled, resourceful and proactive actors and filmmakers. In October 2009, a group of Actors, prompted by a love of films and the desire to achieve the highest calibre of screen acting, created a company of professionals, determined to develop both their artistic and technical abilities for screen. TV drama producer, director and theorist, Michael Ferguson, together with Robert Lewis, the founder of the Lewis Clinic of Cognitive Hypnotherapy in Harley Street, gave their unwavering support and invaluable guidance to this vision and thus the Actors Screen Collective was born.

Our Sponsors

We are delighted to introduce you to our official Grimsby Girl Sponsors, JCS Fish Limited. 

JCS Fish is one of the UK’s leading seafood companies and a specialist in salmon. Founded in 2000 by Andrew and Louise Coulbeck, they have many years’ experience and high quality facilities in Grimsby - at the heart of the UK’s fish processing industry.

We are already making waves in the press ...

http://www.grimsbytelegraph.co.uk/grimsby-girl-retaliates-sacha-baron-cohen-movie/story-29386469-detail/story.html

http://lincolnshirereporter.co.uk/2016/07/grimsby-actress-creating-feel-good-film-response-sasha-baron-cohen-comedy/

What are we Crowd Funding for?

We are seeking to raise £20,000 to help finance this amazing short film. We have some seed investment but need to raise the rest to cover our costs in Production, Post Production and Distribution. Your money will help us with our equipment hire, paying our cast and crew, the production values of the films and the very important post production period

Other Ways You Can Help ...

We fully appreciate that not everyone will be able to contribute but there is still a lot that you can do to help us

  • Follow us on FaceBook and Twitter and share our social media updates
  • Share this campaign with your family and friends
  • @ASCLondon / www.asclondon.com / FB: Actor's Screen Collective

Thank you - your support means the world to us!
story_txt:
Synopsis
When Kelly moves to London from Grimsby to start a new job, she comes prepared for the Northern jibes and sniggering puns.  Taking on a secret identity she seeks to rid London of those who poke fun and bully her leaving a very personal stamp on those who cross her.
Grimsby Girl is a dark, humorous and feel good film where the bad guys get their comeuppance and the good girls kick ass!

The Team
Niya Hill - Writer
Niya is an actress and writer based in London originally from Grimsby. She has worked in theatre, short films and commercials and stays healthy by practising and teaching yoga. Her favourite roles to date have been Arkadina in The Seagull at The Cockpit and Sasha in Coming&Going at the Bush theatre, directed by Rikki Beadle-Blair. She has recently formed her own production company producing and acting in short films. Grimsby Girl is her first short film as a writer.
Anna Keel - Director
Anna Keel is a BBC and Raindance Film School trained director known for a number of acclaimed documentaries before a later branch sideways into the world of drama. Her first short fiction film Seven Stones received special selection at a number of international festivals and her second, Lost Girl, earned her a best director nomination at The Southampton International Film Festival. Her first feature film – a British road movie thriller – is now in the pipeline. In between dreaming up drama Anna continues to make hard hitting, globally successful docs for The BBC, Channel 4, ITV  and more.

story:
I've directed 6 music videos, 2 short films, 4 online ads and a few online documentaries. Each time I've made an effort to try different techniques and styles. The skills I've developed are all going to be needed and employed in the making of my newest project - BLIND FATE!
 
I've written BLIND FATE with themes that I find fascinating, characters I feel I can relate to, and locations that remind me of my child hood, combined with experimental directorial techniques. And we can confidently brag that it’s the first time EVER that a short film is made in this way.

These characters say something about the time we are in. They try take the easy way out of the relationship by making the personal impersonal. They are three people leaning in on each other but when one leg of this balancing act gets pulled the whole thing falls down.


I wanted to play with the hypothetical idea of the multiverse, where infinite universes coexist side by side.  The 3 characters in this intricate multiverse story embody subjects I'm interested in and have written about before, and I've used the premise of a love triangle to connect these characters. One is controlling and keeps the relationship alive with intimidation. One is needy and clings onto someone once they show romantic gestures. One makes choices out of fear and self-service
 
The location for the film is the magnificent rocky coast of Cornwall where we shot the crowdfunding video. The team so far is made up of myself (Writer, Director, Producer), Oliver Nlemadim (Producer) and Adrian Peckitt (Director of Photography).

A new and exciting member of the team is Marion Bergin. She will be our production designer and stylist. Marion brings a lot of expertise and class to the production. Check out Marion's work below! 
 
My previous work  - https://vimeo.com/137265324
 
Adrian's work can be seen here - http://adrianpeckitt.co.uk/showreel/

Marion's work - www.marionbergin.com
 
We are reaching out to just about everyone! Any support, no matter how large or small will be appreciated. THANK YOU for the support!

story:
Who We Are & What We Are Doing

The Paper Football League is a team of passionate filmmakers looking to make clever, entertaining, original films for the indie circuit. Our current project is titled Railed, a dark but humorous story of two damaged people on a final adventure before they jump in front of a train to end it all. The Paper Football League is a fledgling group with no real funding, and we plan to be as creative as we can with that in mind. While we know we can make nothing go a long way, we would be so grateful to have the opportunity to make a little bit go even further.

What We Need

We are looking to raise a minimum of $1100. This will go toward some basic expenses, which we will detail below. Should we raise more than that, we hope to put it toward entering in other festivals, compensating our talent, and The Paper Football League's other productions. 

Our expenses

  • Craft services for 15 people, for 7 days of shooting
  • A generator set up for night shoots (rental)
  • Various equipment rental
  • Film festival entry fee
  • Props
  • Cast and Crew shirts (only if we exceed goal)
  • Compensation for talent (only if we exceed goal)

Why You Want In

The Paper Football League is in its infancy, but the team is already doing more in just one short month than any of us envisioned, and we are gaining traction. This initiative is going to foster amazing collaborations of filmmakers, bringing freshness to the Indie Film scene, and it's all happening in Columbus! This is an excellent opportunity for anyone interested in being a part of enhancing the art scene in this city, and bringing something exciting and new to the area. Who doesn't want to look back and say, "I was there when it all began." Your support means everything to us!

Other Ways You Can Help

We know times are tough. If you can't donate, there are other ways to help!

  • Donate food or cook for a meal for our cast and crew
  • Promote the film or The Paper Football League at your business
  • Network with us on social media: www.facebook,com/thepaperfootballleague
  • Share our campaigns (like this one)
  • Suggest how you think you could help! We welcome it all!

story: Gerda is 75 years old and blind. She now lives alone in the house where she lived with her late husband, a forester. The house is fairly secluded in a wooded area where her husband sometimes took to hunt. Because she is blind, her audience is much beter developed and can she hunt perfectly without being able to see.
