story:
The refugee crisis is the largest recorded human migratory event since WWII. In the past decade, millions of families have fled their homes in search of peace, freedom and a brighter future. After escaping violence in their home countries, they face a treacherous journey to Europe and are often met with opposition, negative media attention, and a lack of resources waiting for them in their host countries. As media coverage has declined, and the story of the modern refugee has been twisted and warped, there are still millions of very real human beings living in fear and uncertainty but continuing to persevere and survive. 

As this global issue becomes more eminent in the eyes of northern Europe and the Western World, the grassroots effort by smaller nonprofit organizations has grown exponentially in the past five years. The IRC states that the refugee population in Greece is approximately 62,000+ (over half of them being women and children). Much of the weight of supporting this crisis has been placed on a country that cannot even fully, economically support itself.

 

 

T H E  F I L M 

During our team’s three week journey through Greece, we followed both refugees and volunteers as they shared their stories of pain, determination and faith. We heard harrowing stories of people crossing the deadly 4 mile stretch between Turkey and Greece, on their journey of escaping violence and war, in hopes of a better life in Europe. We heard stories of families living in camps finding ways to bring normalcy to their children’s lives, volunteers who had their faith in humanity tested and restored, and met with organizations that have found ingenious ways to address the most difficult problems facing refugees living in Europe.

The film will give audiences a look at the present situation in Athens, Lesvos and Thessaloniki and how each location's response to the influx of refugees varies from city-wide effects to local community levels. We take a look at all the incredible hard work being done in small settings, on the ground, from selfless volunteers across the world, and the ways they are working to foster healthier, brighter futures for refugees.

It happened organically that our team consisted entirely of women, and that during our time on the ground, we were met by an army of female volunteers and refugees working together to serve their communities. The film explores an underlying theme of the incredibly strong women on both sides of the crisis, a point of view that hasn't been given a lot of light.

We present the hopes volunteers and refugees have for both the future of the crisis, as well as their own lives. We seek to delve deep into the hearts of what drives these groups to continue on, and how women specifically, have put their lives on hold to help those in need, and have played a vital role in this world wide crisis. We aim to spark conversations and ideas addressing how any viewer of this film, old or young, man or woman, stateside or across the pond can use their skills and passions to bring solutions to the refugee crisis.

By examining what makes us different, we hope to also highlight what makes us the same, forging a connection between refugees and the global community and to ultimately cast a light on those who are frequently disregarded or forgotten.

 

W H A T  M A K E S  U S  D I F F E R E N T

The refugee story is not new. Refugees have existed on almost every continent, since the dawn of civilization. The story has been covered in many ways, through many mediums, but in this moment, the world is lacking a critical piece to the existing refugee narrative.

Many people are familiar with stories of refugees fleeing violence, running through the night, piling into boats and embarking on the open sea to pursue a better life in Europe, but very little is known about what follows. Its pretty easy to assume that refugees are being taken care of. That there are systems in place to provide for them. Our team of eight women embarked on this journey to find out.

What we found is that refugees are still very much fighting for their survival. They are struggling to find meaning in their transient lives and to root themselves in their new countries. This new normal is not headline news, but is the creation of a new global community.

This new normal is refugee women stepping outside of their typical roles to become breadwinners, decision makers, and advocates for their families. This new normal is volunteers working to restore confidence and dignity to parents who haven’t been able to provide for their children. This new normal is European natives putting aside their bias to lend a hand to their Syrian, Iraqi, Pakistani, Eritrean, Nigerian, and Afghan neighbors.

This is the story that is currently unfolding in the social fabric of Greece and beyond. Our team seeks to bring this story to the forefronts of American culture, so we can better learn from our peers and apply these concepts to our daily life.

 

W H Y  W E   N E E D  Y O U R  H E L P 

The eight women who have dedicated their hearts and minds to the production of this film have done so because they truly believe in the importance of its message. In order to carry on their deeds, it is imperative that this film reaches its completion. After successfully reaching its field production wrap date, we are confident and carry positive presuppositions of the film’s completed version.

We’ve assembled a primed post-production team, but now need of your help to move forward with the film's completion. Your funding will assist in editing, scoring, sound design, animation, graphics, FX, contractual management and voice over. We understand making a film is an expensive process, however our team strongly believes in the art of storytelling, and that a story of great importance is meant to be told no matter the cost. This story is too important to keep to ourselves and we cannot wait to share what we have learned with the world.

We hope that you join our cause, become an advocate for ending the refugee crisis and become an ambassador of this film.

All donations made to this campaign will go directly to the post-production of 'Refugee Is Not My Name.'

 

             

               

 

O U R  O R I G I N  S T O R Y

The NPO: The Refugee Relief Project, founded by Megan Majd in 2016 was the the birth place of the documentary concept introduced by Rose Massett that would come to be known as 'Refugee Is Not My Name.’ In early 2016 Majd received the Davis Projects for Peace Grant. Our fellow crew member traveled to refugee camps in France and Greece where she interacted with hundreds of refugees.

The humanitarian effort provided resources to refugees in Europe and sought to raise awareness through filmmaking. Each dollar the project collected went directly to individuals, families, and volunteers at camps and squats around Greece.

Although efforts were and have been exerted to help those in need, our crew realized it was not enough. The world needed a sensory experience to understand the true magnitude of the refugee crisis. So therefore, in March 2017 our team of eight was assemble to give a voice to those that needed to be heard thousands of miles away.

 

              

 

O U R  T E A M 

We are filmmakers, artists, entrepreneurs, human rights advocates, producers, musicians, writers, students, healthcare consultants, composers, climate change leaders, engineers, community leaders, journalists and so much more. Each of us made a decision to go to Greece, to visit and help people who didn’t look like us, didn’t speak our language, didn’t practice the same faith, but we all went for one binding reason. Because we cared, and because it matters.

We have the backgrounds and the experience to make this documentary a full fledged reality. We are so incredibly close, but we need the support to make this dream finally come true. But even more so, we are the ones to make it happen, to share a story and a perspective never been seen before, because more than anything, we care. We have been there, we have met these people. We have learned their names, shared meals with them and listened to their stories. Their strife became our inspiration, and we won’t stop until we’ve done right by them and ensured that their stories are told.

Rose Massett (Director/ Producer / Writer / Director of Photography) is a graduate of New York University's Tisch School of the Arts, where she earned a degree in Film and Television production, with an emphasis on producing and ​entertainment business. She has worked with several non-profits including Operation Smile. In 2010, she traveled to India to volunteer on a medical mission, where her passion to create films that inspire social change was born. She was a member of Operation Smile's Executive Leadership Council, and a host of their International Student Leadership Conference. Driven by her passion to tell important stories, and her desire to inspire social change through art, Rose continues her love of film and television through writing, producing and directing in Los Angeles.

Megan Majd (Producer, Global Human Relations Director, Founder of R.R.P.) studied human rights and environmental policy at UC Berkeley. As a student she ran advocacy campaigns, was elected to student government, and worked to reform the universities sexual assault policies. In the past two years, Megan has received the John Gardner Public Service Fellowship, the Generation Jobless Employment Innovation Grant, and the Davis Projects for Peace. She founded a marketing agency for social enterprises and nonprofits called Outlaww that she runs in San Francisco full-time.  Megan is currently building a mobile application that will allow refugees to work on their smartphones, for more information, see www.harmoniapp.com 

Megan Towle (Producer / Writer / Director of Photography)  graduated from the College of Saint Benedict with a degree is Global Business Leadership, a minor in communications, and a focus in Entrepreneurship. During her time at Saint Ben's, Megan was a member of Extending the Link - a student run documentary team with a mission to use documentary film as a vehicle for social change. In 2014, the team traveled to Thailand and Myanmar to film the stories of Karen refugees living along the border in refugee camps. This introduced Megan to the stories of refugees and connected her to the refugee community both at home and abroad. Megan became director of the team her senior year, and furthered her passion for igniting change through film. Megan currently works at UnitedHealth Group in Minneapolis as a healthcare consultant.

Rebecca Banks (Producer /Director of Photography/ Writing Department Editor / Marketing and PR Director) studied film production and arts administration with an emphasis in Public Affairs at Indiana University of Bloomington. She presently works as an independent filmmaker in Los Angeles, CA. As a student Banks worked to promote film making within the Indiana region and is striving to change tax incentives for local filmmakers. Banks's work is a medley of varying artistic interests. She has developed public affairs and marketing campaigns for the Smithsonian's National Museum of American History. As well as assisted in the development and release of the award winning film, The Good Catholic; as well as acclaimed AMC television series Breaking Bad and pre-series Better Call Saul in assistant directing. Banks is currently aiming to work on several documentary and narrative films addressing issues in human rights, deaf culture and the LBGTQ community.

Penka Kouneva (Composer) is known across Hollywood as an exceptionally talented composer and an artist of uncommon passion. Her credits include the games Prince of Persia and Transformers (with themes by Steve Jablonsky - the Transformers composer, for whom she has worked since 2004). She has scored on her own a dozen indie features: the breakout films for Chloe Moretz and Josh Duhamel; Devil's Whisper distributed by Sony Pictures and currently, the SciFi drama feature Encounter starring Luke Hemsworth from Westworld. She has also scored TV, games and The Mummy VR experience at the IMAX VR theaters around the world. Recently Penka composed for the American Astronauts. The $30M NASA exhibit at the Kennedy Space Center Heroes and Legends  features her score for 3D films and installations. She is a Universal Music-released composer (The Woman Astronaut orchestral album). In addition to her career as a composer, she has also orchestrated for Hans Zimmer, Neal Acree (Blizzard Entertainment), and on some of the biggest films and games (Matrix, Transformers, Pirates 3, Elysium, Enders Game, Ninja Turtles, Gears of War, Sims).  

Clinton Jones (Dialogue Editor / Sound Mixer) Clinton Jones’ career in sound started out as a self taught live sound engineer and then, after deciding to go to audio school, the world of post-production sound became the clear choice for his career. Upon completing school, Clinton was fortunate enough to land at the top of the game industry food-chain, Blizzard Entertainment.  Building on a solid foundation from school, he quickly earned the respect of his colleagues and spent the next 3 ½ years pushing himself to be the best he could.  2014 would be a highlight year that began with an M.P.S.E. Golden Reel award for his contribution to StarCraft 2: Heart of the Swarm. Since leaving Blizzard in 2014 Clinton has worked on a number of independent films, TV commercials and numerous video games. Clinton lives in Southern California with his wife and four kids.

Callie Chamberlain (Associate Producer) is committed to advancing social justice and entrepreneurship after witnessing the extreme disparities in our health and education systems. She has spent time in corporate, not-for-profit, community, philanthropic, and government organizations. Most recently, Callie has led the development of innovation frameworks and the build out of data-driven business intelligence across Optum's Innovation Research & Development organization. Drawing upon her background in health disparities and social justice, she consults for the Robert Wood Johnson Foundation and supports the development of community-based giving strategies with the F.R. Bigelow Foundation. Callie is a co-founder of New-Leaders Council Twin Cities, a cross-sector leadership and development program connecting progressive leaders with a goal to make Minneapolis-St. Paul more equitable. As co-founder, she contributes to the Make It MSP initiative focused on supporting and retaining leaders of color in the region. She is a 2014 National Urban Fellow and a World Economic Forum Global Shaper. In her free time she organizes political t-shirt pop-up shops, reads, cooks, dreams, and spends time with her loved ones.

Hayley Bosworth (Associate Producer) is an undergraduate student at University of San Francisco, majoring in Peace and Justice Studies. As a high school student participating in the International Baccalaureate Diploma Programme, her Community Action Service assignment led her into an internship with a local non-profit March to the Top. Immediately she began investing herself into their newest project, New Hope Orphanage in Meru, Kenya, which houses 115 HIV-positive children who have been abandoned for inability to afford treatment or orphaned after their HIV positive parents passed away. This became Hayley’s biggest passion moving forward and into college. While interning in the International Republican Institute’s Middle East and North African Division in Washington DC, the devastation of Ramadan inspired her take action in whatever form possible. 

Sasha Chebil (Associate Producer) graduated from UC Berkeley, with degrees in English Literature and Media, and shortly after moved to Berlin where she currently resides. Living there over the course of three years has allowed her to witness the refugee situation first hand- volunteering at shelters and helping with local integration through social events and cultural exchange. Over the course of the last 7 years, Sasha has worked in the music industry, both as a music booker and journalist. Motivated by her passion for music, she currently finds independent artists stages to play on throughout Europe. In her spare time, Sasha writes for a non-profit music publication focused on social awareness and positive change. 

Yassamin Ansari (Associate Producer) is a graduate student at the University of Cambridge studying international relations and politics. Previously, she served as the Director of the Climate Action 2016 multi-stakeholder summit and as a member of the climate team that advised the UN Secretary-General and helped to deliver the historic Paris Agreement. As an undergraduate student at Stanford, Yassamin interned for Congresswoman Nancy Pelosi, led a global advocacy and fundraising campaign for Syria Deeply, and graduated with honors in international security studies. She is also the founder of the Ansari Fellowship Program, and works as a strategy coordinator for Mission 2020— a climate action initiative under the leadership of former UN climate chief Christiana Figueres. 

 

              

              

 

W H A T  W E  N E E D 

BREAKDOWN OF BUDGET 

All of the donations made to this campaign will go directly to post-production costs for the film. A breakdown of the budget is as follows:

Editorial Costs: 32%

Composer/ Sound Mixing/ Orchestra Recording: 32%

Copyright/ Legal Costs: 10%

Graphics/Animation: 7%

Distribution Costs: 7%

Public Relation/Contractual Management/Accounting Fees: 7%

Miscellaneous Production Costs: 5%


       

  


You have the ability to play a key role in advocating the pressing issue of the refugee crisis. The faces that are set to appear on screen represent masses of displaced souls who have been disregarded and trivialized by the mass media. We hope that with the production and completion of this film that we may bring a change in perception, action and commitment to refugees around Europe.  

Our efforts to screen these inspiring stories cannot take effect unless we have your support. I urge you to partner with The Refugee Project Production Company as a sponsor, donor or collaborator in order to help drive our post-production campaign for Summer 2017.

‘Refugee Is Not My Name’ is set to release in early 2018.

 

PARTNERS/SPONSORING ORGANIZATIONS

The EKO Project

The Hope Project

Armando Aid

The Worldwide Tribe

Humans 4 Humanity

If you can not make a donation at this time, please help by sharing our story on social media  (Facebook, Twitter, Instagram, LinkedIn, etc) or by word of mouth!

For more information on the Refugee Relief Project, please visit our website or contact our Marketing and PR Director, Rebecca Elena Banks. 

Website:

http://refugeereliefproject.com/

Thank you for your partnership and support!

 

All photos courtesy of Rose Massett, Rebecca Banks & Megan Towle.
story_txt: The refugee crisis is the largest recorded human migratory event since WWII. In the past decade, millions of families have fled their homes in search of peace, freedom and a brighter future. After escaping violence in their home countries, they face a treacherous journey to Europe and are often met with opposition, negative media attention, and a lack of resources waiting for them in their host countries. As media coverage has declined, and the story of the modern refugee has been twisted and warped, there are still millions of very real human beings living in fear and uncertainty but continuing to persevere and survive. As this global issue becomes more eminent in the eyes of northern Europe and the Western World, the grassroots effort by smaller nonprofit organizations has grown exponentially in the past five years. The IRC states that the refugee population in Greece is approximately 62,000+ (over half of them being women and children). Much of the weight of supporting this crisis has been placed on a country that cannot even fully, economically support itself.  T H E  F I L M During our team’s three week journey through Greece, we followed both refugees and volunteers as they shared their stories of pain, determination and faith. We heard harrowing stories of people crossing the deadly 4 mile stretch between Turkey and Greece, on their journey of escaping violence and war, in hopes of a better life in Europe. We heard stories of families living in camps finding ways to bring normalcy to their children’s lives, volunteers who had their faith in humanity tested and restored, and met with organizations that have found ingenious ways to address the most difficult problems facing refugees living in Europe.The film will give audiences a look at the present situation in Athens, Lesvos and Thessaloniki and how each location's response to the influx of refugees varies from city-wide effects to local community levels. We take a look at all the incredible hard work being done in small settings, on the ground, from selfless volunteers across the world, and the ways they are working to foster healthier, brighter futures for refugees.It happened organically that our team consisted entirely of women, and that during our time on the ground, we were met by an army of female volunteers and refugees working together to serve their communities. The film explores an underlying theme of the incredibly strong women on both sides of the crisis, a point of view that hasn't been given a lot of light.We present the hopes volunteers and refugees have for both the future of the crisis, as well as their own lives. We seek to delve deep into the hearts of what drives these groups to continue on, and how women specifically, have put their lives on hold to help those in need, and have played a vital role in this world wide crisis. We aim to spark conversations and ideas addressing how any viewer of this film, old or young, man or woman, stateside or across the pond can use their skills and passions to bring solutions to the refugee crisis.By examining what makes us different, we hope to also highlight what makes us the same, forging a connection between refugees and the global community and to ultimately cast a light on those who are frequently disregarded or forgotten. W H A T  M A K E S  U S  D I F F E R E N TThe refugee story is not new. Refugees have existed on almost every continent, since the dawn of civilization. The story has been covered in many ways, through many mediums, but in this moment, the world is lacking a critical piece to the existing refugee narrative.Many people are familiar with stories of refugees fleeing violence, running through the night, piling into boats and embarking on the open sea to pursue a better life in Europe, but very little is known about what follows. Its pretty easy to assume that refugees are being taken care of. That there are systems in place to provide for them. Our team of eight women embarked on this journey to find out.What we found is that refugees are still very much fighting for their survival. They are struggling to find meaning in their transient lives and to root themselves in their new countries. This new normal is not headline news, but is the creation of a new global community.This new normal is refugee women stepping outside of their typical roles to become breadwinners, decision makers, and advocates for their families. This new normal is volunteers working to restore confidence and dignity to parents who haven’t been able to provide for their children. This new normal is European natives putting aside their bias to lend a hand to their Syrian, Iraqi, Pakistani, Eritrean, Nigerian, and Afghan neighbors.This is the story that is currently unfolding in the social fabric of Greece and beyond. Our team seeks to bring this story to the forefronts of American culture, so we can better learn from our peers and apply these concepts to our daily life. W H Y  W E   N E E D  Y O U R  H E L P The eight women who have dedicated their hearts and minds to the production of this film have done so because they truly believe in the importance of its message. In order to carry on their deeds, it is imperative that this film reaches its completion. After successfully reaching its field production wrap date, we are confident and carry positive presuppositions of the film’s completed version.We’ve assembled a primed post-production team, but now need of your help to move forward with the film's completion. Your funding will assist in editing, scoring, sound design, animation, graphics, FX, contractual management and voice over. We understand making a film is an expensive process, however our team strongly believes in the art of storytelling, and that a story of great importance is meant to be told no matter the cost. This story is too important to keep to ourselves and we cannot wait to share what we have learned with the world.We hope that you join our cause, become an advocate for ending the refugee crisis and become an ambassador of this film.All donations made to this campaign will go directly to the post-production of 'Refugee Is Not My Name.'                               O U R  O R I G I N  S T O R YThe NPO: The Refugee Relief Project, founded by Megan Majd in 2016 was the the birth place of the documentary concept introduced by Rose Massett that would come to be known as 'Refugee Is Not My Name.’ In early 2016 Majd received the Davis Projects for Peace Grant. story:
Hey you. Yes, you. Keep reading. 

Hi. My name is Steven Olson, and I'm an independent filmmaker from Las Vegas, Nevada.  For over a year, I've been working on a personal film project of mine.  This film, tentatively titled Story Search, is a comedy about a Narrator who struggles to control the actions of the characters in the stories he tells, resulting in his own personal struggle to control his life and actions.  For a short excerpt of the script, click here: https://drive.google.com/open?id=0B1QgnLza2I0XOHZmQWlrQU04ajQ

I've wanted to be a storyteller since I was 8 years old, whether it be through acting, writing, singing, theater, or film.  This project will help me in my lifelong quest to tell thoughtful, engaging, and entertaining stories.  And you can be a part of this film's production and help inspire others through its story and life-affirming message.

Where's the money going?

The money raised from this campaign will go towards renting the camera and lighting equipment that we need to shoot the film.  We have already received some grant money, which will help us pay our cast and buy props and costumes for the film, and we already have most of our cast and crew ready and waiting to work.  These additional funds will help us afford all of the lights, camera lenses, tripods, and other filming essentials that we'll need to make the best film possible, and may also help us with film festival submission fees once it's ready to be exhibited.

Your Impact

By donating to this project, you would help to fund a story that has an inspiring and relevant message for modern audiences.  This particular film was inspired from a walk through the London countryside where I spied an old man sitting on a bench by a stream, and I wondered what his story was.  Failing to come up with a creative, engaging story that I could turn into a novel, I realized that this man's life didn't need to have a thrilling, award winning narrative or my own personal validation for it to be valuable.  So I wrote a story about a Narrator who slowly learns the value of free will and life itself, and in doing so, learns to take control of his life and accept the things in life that he cannot change. Besides simply entertaining the audience with jokes and funny situations, I believe this film will help people think about the value of their own personal free will and the amount of control that we have, and sometimes don't have, in our own lives.

Rest assured, your money won't be wasted on a crew full of inexperienced filmmakers.  We have assembled an excellent crew who love the script and are dedicated to the project.  I have personally written and directed several short films already, and I have worked on various film projects over the last 2 years. 

Risks and Challenges

Like with any film project, there are inherent risks involved.  There might be weather issues on the days that we planned to shoot outside.  Some equipment might malfunction on set, causing delays.  However, I am confident that we will be able to surpass any obstacles.  We have some of the finest young filmmakers in Utah working on this project, and I trust them with my life.  As of now, our shooting dates are scheduled for July 27th, 28th, and 29th, and we are working very hard towards finishing the film by September 2017.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you aren't able to donate, but you still want to support the art of film making and storytelling, spread the word about our project, and share this project with your friends and family on Facebook and other social networking sites!  Thank you!

short excerpt of the script, click here: https://drive.google.com/open?id=0B1QgnLza2I0XOHZmQWlrQU04ajQI've wanted to be a storyteller since I was 8 years old, whether it be through acting, writing, singing, theater, or film.  This project will help me in my lifelong quest to tell thoughtful, engaging, and entertaining stories.  And you can be a part of this film's production and help inspire others through its story and life-affirming message.Where's the money going?The money raised from this campaign will go towards renting the camera and lighting equipment that we need to shoot the film.  We have already received some grant money, which will help us pay our cast and buy props and costumes for the film, and we already have most of our cast and crew ready and waiting to work.  These additional funds will help us afford all of the lights, camera lenses, tripods, and other filming essentials that we'll need to make the best film possible, and may also help us with film festival submission fees once it's ready to be exhibited.Your ImpactBy donating to this project, you would help to fund a story that has an inspiring and relevant message for modern audiences.  This particular film was inspired from a walk through the London countryside where I spied an old man sitting on a bench by a stream, and I wondered what his story was.  Failing to come up with a creative, engaging story that I could turn into a novel, I realized that this man's life didn't need to have a thrilling, award winning narrative or my own personal validation for it to be valuable.  So I wrote a story about a Narrator who slowly learns the value of free will and life itself, and in doing so, learns to take control of his life and accept the things in life that he cannot change. Besides simply entertaining the audience with jokes and funny situations, I believe this film will help people think about the value of their own personal free will and the amount of control that we have, and sometimes don't have, in our own lives.Rest assured, your money won't be wasted on a crew full of inexperienced filmmakers.  We have assembled an excellent crew who love the script and are dedicated to the project.  I have personally written and directed several short films already, and I have worked on various film projects over the last 2 years. Risks and ChallengesLike with any film project, there are inherent risks involved.  There might be weather issues on the days that we planned to shoot outside.  Some equipment might malfunction on set, causing delays.  However, I am confident that we will be able to surpass any obstacles.  We have some of the finest young filmmakers in Utah working on this project, and I trust them with my life.  As of now, our shooting dates are scheduled for July 27th, 28th, and 29th, and we are working very hard towards finishing the film by September 2017.Other Ways You Can HelpIf you aren't able to donate, but you still want to support the art of film making and storytelling, spread the word about our project, and share this project with your friends and family on Facebook and other social networking sites!  Thank you!

story:
Purpose and Impact

Most refugees living in Athens are appreciative of the work of international volunteers, but it's not uncommon to hear some form of this sentiment:

"If you really want to help, convince your government to accept more refugees."

Refugees are still trapped, detained, and ostracized in Europe, and aid organizations are limited in their ability fix this problem.  At some point, the keys are in the hands of our governments; and in order to convince our governments, we must work to sway public opinion in the right direction.  This is why we want to make this film. Not only to commit to memory the stories of so many people in anonymity, but to ultimately create tangible ways to help them, and allow them to help themselves.  

A short piece from the filmmakers, using some preliminary footage shot by Alex during his work in Athens.

This Isn't A Typical Documentary

Your donations don't merely fund a film; they support a process of filmmaking that is imperative, yet rare in this genre.

  • Empowerment- We're dedicated to giving refugees tools that they can take with them wherever they go.  Our featured "Sponsor" perk is a chance to sponsor a refugee by funding a personal filmmaking course for them.  This course will culminate in a short film, written and directed by the sponsored person.  This gives the world a chance to hear from refugees directly, and it teaches a set of invaluable skills that can be used internationally.
  • Ethics- Your support is crucial to making this documentary as ethically as possible.  Larger, more direct forms of funding often require revenue, which can lead to exploitative filmmaking.  Your donations will allow the filmmakers to approach this story with utmost sensitivity to the potential liabilities of the subjects, without monetary pressures from outside funders. We'll remain open in our intentions and steadfast in our resolve to ensure none of our subjects are exploited or misrepresented.

  • Experience- Building trust is not easy. You can't just walk up to someone as ask if you can tell their story. That person has to believe in what you're doing and want to help you do it.  After months working in Athens, Alex has a personal connection with people and places which will enrich this film and turn it into the dynamic piece we know it can be.

Who Are The Filmmakers?

Not only do we think there is a story to be told, but after months of first-hand experience and contextual research, we think we're the ones to go and tell it.

A L E X   N E Z A M  

(director)

Alex is extremely passionate about our international responsibility to refugees.  Alex found the motivation to make this film after 4 months in Athens working with multiple volunteer organizations.  After noticing the limitations of those organizations, and the reliance upon governments to affect long-term change, he concluded that turning to media would be the most productive use of his efforts.  He offers unique insight into the local situation concerning refugees that is critical for the production of this documentary.

A N T H O N Y   B U R G E S E N

(producer/assistant director)

Tony has been working on documentary films covering historical events including the rebuilding effort in New Orleans after Katrina, and the socio-political restructuring in Ferguson, MO after the Michael Brown shooting. His familiarity with documentary style shooting, especially in humanitarian efforts, grants an insight and skill valuable to making this film.

Z A P H I R I S   E P A M I N O N D A S  

(director of photography)

Zaphiris lives and works in Athens.  Zaphiris has been DP for over 500 commercials over the course of his career.  He's worked for production houses in Dubai, Hong Kong, Cyprus, Tunisia, and Saudi Arabia, and has considerable experience shooting in the documentary genre.  His comfort and familiarity with the surrounding environment and to the subject demographic make him valuable asset to the production team.

We take this project very seriously because we know how critical the situation is.  We know the tremendous social asset of a well-made documentary, and we are aware of the potential risks and rewards.  This principled approach is endemic to our workflow.  We have been working together media projects since 2010 and have successfully completed a number of films together.  This team is committed to the same ideals for a unique and unified cinematic vision.  

How Will The Funding Be Used?

The funds contributed go directly to this project in a variety of ways, including:

  • Equipment - for this film we want to use high-quality camcorders for general filming and interviews, a solid DSLR for static shots, basic lighting kits for the interviews, and good quality microphones and recording devices. We believe the better the equipment, the better the overall project is going to be.

  • Production and Crew- While in Athens, the crew will need a places to stay, food, and general amenities, as well as applying for permits to shoot in certain areas restricted to general tourists.

  • Travel and Transportation - Little is predetermined in Athens.  Many refugees don't know where they will be from one week to the next.  The ability to move throughout Greece in order to follow the critical stories is important for the success of this documentary.

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute monetarily, but that doesn't mean they can't help:

  • Check out our website and share it with your friends and family!  https://www.athensrefugeeproject.com/
  • Like and share our Facebook page with your friends and family!
  • Follow us on Twitter and Instagram!
  • And be sure to use the IndieGoGo share tools!

Any additional questions you might have after checking out our IndieGoGo, feel free to contact us on any social medium, or you can e-mail us directly at atheniancondition@gmail.com.

story:
Short Summary

Hi Everyone! I truly appreciate you guys taking the time to see what I’m up to next. As you can see, after having great success with my first film...due to the love and support from you guys, I was motivated to do another. I'm excited about this one because it's a documentary about the obsession people have on social media with the filters and photo enhancements apps.

Why I need your support 

As an independent writer and director, I'm working on a very tight budget. I shot this film on little to no budget at all. I wanted to be a little creative, so I filmed 70% of the film on my iphone7...which cost me nothing. I am now done filming and need a little help with editing/post production (USD $2, 500). Which is the most important part of a film project.  

Your contribution will help pay for  post-production.  Be well assured that every contributed dollar will only be used for the completion of this film. I’m very passionate about this project and I can’t wait to share it with all of you.

About the Writer,  Director, and Producer

Isaac has earned a Daytime Emmy Nomination and won two NAACP Image Awards. He is currently a TV Producer on TvOne’s number one show, Unsung and Unsung Hollywood. Throughout Isaac’s career, he has worked for CBS, Sony, Paramount, and 20th Century FOX.  He produced on Court shows, Talk shows, Reality shows, Clip shows, and Documentaries. Outside of his day to day producing gig, Isaac has assisted in casting, editing, reenactments, created a social networking website, and produced his own pilot.

Other Ways You Can Help

I understand not everyone can contribute cash, but you can give in other ways. I ask that you please share this campaign across your social networks and with family and friends that are not on social media. The more people who are aware of the campaign and the film, the better chances I have to hit this goal.

story:
Story

I read Raymond Carver's short story "Why Don't You Dance?" a year ago and ever since, I haven't been able to get it out of my head. It tells a story that strikes many of its readers because of its blatant lack of exposition or explanation for the strange environment it throws its readers into - an unusual yard sale hosted by a mysterious and solemn middle-aged man. In the story, a young couple attend this yard sale and the three characters share an oddly intimate experience on this lawn filled with all of the man's possessions and memories. In the end, the three characters go their separate ways and we, the onlookers, are left to ponder this strange and beautiful encounter. 

This eerie departure from a traditional narrative setup rings a kind of truth that we hope to replicate in our film — that life doesn’t come with plot points and that ambiguity is often more beautiful than explanation. In the absence of a traditional narrative setup, we hope to provide our audience with a fundamentally emotional experience that plays with their expectations, rather than plays out narrative conventions.

"Not For Sale" is an experimental film which follows its main character, Jack, a man in his mid-50's who has recently lost his wife. He hosts a yard sale in order to rid himself of all of his worldly possessions that are stained with her memory. A young couple, Henry and Sarah, attend Jack's sale and are forced to encounter the fact that Jack's memories have a way of creeping into their reality.

Our Production

This is Julia's junior year thesis at NYU's Tisch School of the Arts. She has assembled a crew of fellow student filmmakers who have agreed to help her bring her project to life. The production team is currently in the midst of preparing for their mid-November shoot when our team of 17 will travel to Connecticut for 2 days of principle photography. After 2-3 months of post production, we will submit our final product to festivals around the country and post the film online in late 2018.

Budget Breakdown

Filmmaking is an incredible and collaborative art form, but it is also a very expensive one. In order to make this project happen, we are hoping to raise $4,500 that will cover our crucial production costs.

Any and all donations are greatly appreciated. With your help, we hope to make a film that we can be proud of and we look forward to sharing it with you.

Meet the Team

Julia Kupiec (Writer/Director)

Julia is a director and cinematographer from Santa Barbara, California. She is amazed at storytelling's ability to evoke empathy toward situations that many of us may never actually encounter in our lifetimes. She sees it as a way to experience more of life than we would have been able to through our narrow perspectives. During Julia's time at NYU, she has worked on dozens of student and professional productions across many departments. She has served professionally as a cinematographer, gaffer, editor and assistant camera and is very excited to bring her experience to the directing table. At 17, her directorial debut "Anonymous" was featured in the Santa Barbara International Film Festival but since coming to NYU, she has devoted herself to her work as an aspiring cinematographer. She is incredibly excited to return to the role of director on this film and be able to apply all of the knowledge and experience she has gained toward creating a project she can feel proud of. 

Ellie Dworkin (Producer) & Matt Foundoulis (Producer / Grip)

Ellie Dworkin is a film and television student at New York University's Tisch School of the Arts. She is an aspiring Executive Producer, pursuing a double minor in Business Studies and the Business of Entertainment, Media and Technology in hopes of refining her expertise. Amongst her latest work, she produced a mock-umentary reality webseries, produced a music video, and was a part time general/sales intern for Filmnation Ent. She’s excited to be collaborating with Julia again.

Matthew Foundoulis is a Senior in the Film and Television Production program at New York University’s Tisch School of the Arts. While he is normally seen working behind the camera as a Director of Photography, Matthew chose to join the producing team on “Not For Sale” alongside Ellie with the intention of bringing his extensive technical knowledge and experience to the table. Coming from a creative background, Matthew will not only assist in the logistics of putting the project together, but also ensure that Julia is able to achieve the visually stunning short film that she has set out to make.

Ace Buckley (Cinematographer)

Ace Buckley is a senior in NYU’s film and television program. Originating from Los Angeles, Ace has grown up on set. His entire family is in the film business and he would talk about lighting setups with his father over dinner. He has shot many a intermediate film and gaffed even more, from thesis films to professional productions. He’s not afraid to crack a joke or a lens. Just kidding. He is extremely excited and feels privileged to be part of this project.

Jacob Fertig (Production Designer)

Jacob Fertig is exicted to work on "Not For Sale." His background in fine art, construction, and filmmaking inform his work as a production designer. He frequently uses found objects and transforms them into set pieces. His design work stems from a love of upcycled art and sustainable architecture. He is humbled to collaborate with Julia on their fourth film together!

Claire Stacy (Assistant Director)

Claire Stacy is a senior in NYU’s film and television program. She is most commonly found producing and assistant directing films and other projects. Originally from San Francisco, Claire has worked on a number of sets in many different roles and has interned at companies like RSA, Pomp&Clout, and “The Daily Show." She claims to enjoy the stress of producing and assistant directing, but we’ll let you be the judge of that. She also doesn’t like almond milk.

Alex Kary (Gaffer)

Alex is originally from Kentucky and is now a Junior at NYU studying Film and TV. She is primarily a gaffer and has worked in G&E on many productions in her three years at NYU. She has worked with many of the crew members before and is excited to work with them again on Not for Sale.

How You Can Help

Every donation, big or small, will help to bring this project to life. If you can't donate, you can still make a difference! Share our campaign with your family and friends and help us spread the word. We're incredibly excited about this film and we hope you are too. Lets make it a reality!

story:
The FILM

Rolling In The Deep: A Crime Drama that follows the life of Marcus Washington, An African American Male who served in the United States Armed Forces as a member of the 761st Tank Battalion(Black Panthers) who travels back home to South Carolina after the war.

Marcus has one agenda on his mind and that's to achieve a dream of his late Father Earl, eating a meal at a locally famous Whites Only Diner.

This film sheds light on a major part of African American history often overlooked and seldom mentioned. This is done through a Father and Son, who put their lives on the line for this country during WW1 then WW2 as part of two unknown but significantly important combat regiments, the Harlem Hellfighters & General Patton's 761st Tank Battalion. Once the war is over a new story begins as these combat vets test how far ones love will go to achieve a dream while defending the honor of a fellow Soldier, Father and American.

 

The Filmmaker

Marcellus Cox is a Award-Winning Filmmaker from Los Angeles, California. Marcellus has always had a passion for Movies, Filmmaking and Storytelling. His filming style deals with dark/edgy themes pushing the limits as far as he can possible go with his storytelling touching on subjects such as Race, Religion, Social & Political issues.

Marcellus Cox's Work has been seen in over 100 Different Film Festivals across the globe including the likes of the fame Cannes Film Festival.

The Producer

Armando Townsend is the Executive Producer behind Rolling In The Deep. Armando's passion and love for this story goes way beyond measure. His amazing knowledge for Film Production and Historical Fiction makes him the perfect man to helm this picture in the right direction.

What We Need!!!!!!!!

As of October 2017 Rolling In The Deep has been in 30 Film Festivals World Wide and has Won 5 Awards on it's amazing Festival Run. But were back running this Campaign because we need your help too make another successful Festival Run in 2018.. We've set our campaign goal at $500 which will help us with Festival Fees and if we raise more it will also cover Film Prints for the screenings.

In exchange for every donation we receive we will share our appreciation and gratitude by giving you a Special Thank You credit in the Re-Release Version of the film as well as on the Social Media Pages..

THANK YOU FOR YOUR SUPPORT!!!!!

Even if you can donate all we ask is that you share the film and link with Friends, Family, everyone in your inner circle. And once again we Thank each and every one of you for taking the time to review this campaign.

For More Information Please Contact:
Writer/Director - Marcellus Cox
facebook.com/marcelluscox24
facebook.com/RollingInTheDeepFilm/

story_txt:
The FILM
Rolling In The Deep: A Crime Drama that follows the life of Marcus Washington, An African American Male who served in the United States Armed Forces as a member of the 761st Tank Battalion(Black Panthers) who travels back home to South Carolina after the war.
Marcus has one agenda on his mind and that's to achieve a dream of his late Father Earl, eating a meal at a locally famous Whites Only Diner.
This film sheds light on a major part of African American history often overlooked and seldom mentioned. This is done through a Father and Son, who put their lives on the line for this country during WW1 then WW2 as part of two unknown but significantly important combat regiments, the Harlem Hellfighters & General Patton's 761st Tank Battalion. Once the war is over a new story begins as these combat vets test how far ones love will go to achieve a dream while defending the honor of a fellow Soldier, Father and American.

 


The Filmmaker
Marcellus Cox is a Award-Winning Filmmaker from Los Angeles, California. Marcellus has always had a passion for Movies, Filmmaking and Storytelling. His filming style deals with dark/edgy themes pushing the limits as far as he can possible go with his storytelling touching on subjects such as Race, Religion, Social & Political issues.
Marcellus Cox's Work has been seen in over 100 Different Film Festivals across the globe including the likes of the fame Cannes Film Festival.
The Producer
Armando Townsend is the Executive Producer behind Rolling In The Deep. Armando's passion and love for this story goes way beyond measure. His amazing knowledge for Film Production and Historical Fiction makes him the perfect man to helm this picture in the right direction.
What We Need!!!!!!!!
As of October 2017 Rolling In The Deep has been in 30 Film Festivals World Wide and has Won 5 Awards on it's amazing Festival Run. But were back running this Campaign because we need your help too make another successful Festival Run in 2018.. We've set our campaign goal at $500 which will help us with Festival Fees and if we raise more it will also cover Film Prints for the screenings.
In exchange for every donation we receive we will share our appreciation and gratitude by giving you a Special Thank You credit in the Re-Release Version of the film as well as on the Social Media Pages..
THANK YOU FOR YOUR SUPPORT!!!!!
Even if you can donate all we ask is that you share the film and link with Friends, Family, everyone in your inner circle. And once again we Thank each and every one of you for taking the time to review this campaign.
For More Information Please Contact:Writer/Director - Marcellus Coxfacebook.com/marcelluscox24facebook.com/RollingInTheDeepFilm/coxmarcellus@gmail.com

story:
Short Summary

Three soldiers, Bobby, Michael and Will, are walking through the jungle in Vietnam when Bobby hears a click. He stepped on a mine. Will goes to work on the mine to disarm it while Michael takes a knees and keeps an eye out for enemies. Bobby remains still and begins to talk with Michael to sooth his nerves. Eventually, Bobby settles on a memory and recounts the time he was on a hot streak playing craps at a small bar in Texas.

The bar was crowded and the alley they played craps in was full. Bobby was winning everything and shouted he could beat the devil if he were there. Thats when he appeared. He walked in and challenged Bobby, taking everything he had. On the last roll, Bobby played for his soul and prays. He won. But the devil, now upset, tells Bobby he will revisit him in exactly one year from that day. June 24. Bobby goes on to explain that in that year, he was drafted and survived in countless battles leading up to today. The days blurred together and he lost track of time. That’s when Bobby, now on the mine, asks Michael what the day is. Michael then responds with “It’s June 24.”

Who are we?

Brandon Rendon-Torres (Writer/Director)

I am a student and filmmaker in Austin, Tx. I absolutely love film, creating and all things storytelling. In the past, I have directed, shot, and crewed on over 30 films and don't plan on stopping anytime soon. One day, I hope to direct feature films as well as write them. 

This project means a lot to me because it will be my final project for the University and it will give me another chance to direct and gain more experience. The story itself was based off of a play written by a dear friend of mine and I loved it! I want to go out with a bang and I know this film will be amazing!

Here are a couple of links to my previous works:

Keep Quiet - https://vimeo.com/205005299

Fractured - https://vimeo.com/216934770

Elijahwan Butler (Producer)

A film student at the University of Texas at Austin. Born and raised on the rural outskirts of San Antonio, I spent my childhood exploring Texas hill country with a camera. Since then, I’ve written, directed, and produced over 50 short films, and crewed in every department on many more films. In the past year, I produced 2 web series, worked as 1st AC on Bloody Drama, a horror feature film coming to Amazon Prime this winter, and directed/produced a portion of Texas Terror Tales, a horror anthology feature that screened out local art-house theaters in San Antonio and McAllen, Texas.

Corbin Heinchon (Associate Producer)

I'm a University of Texas student and producer based in Austin, Texas. I've worked as an associate producer, assistant director, and production assistant on short films, music videos, and television advertisements, as well as worked with Austin Film Festival, Austin Film Society, and South by Southwest. I also have been an assistant editor on promotional videos for companies like H-E-B, WellMed, and others during my time with the IMG studio in San Antonio, Texas.

 

What We Need & What You Get

We need your help to secure locations, feed our cast and crew, and purchase props and costumes. With your generous donation, you will receive perks ranging from stickers, early access to the film, all the way to a credit  in the film!

The Impact

This film will be produced entirely by students. All the cast and crew will be working on this film because they are as passionate about the project as we are! This film will help them learn more about the filmmaking process and help them reach their career goals.

Other Ways You Can Help

We would love it if you could contribute, but we completely understand if you can't. It isn't for everybody.

Even so, we would appreciate it if you pass the page along and share our campaign with someone you think might be interested. You can even share it with someone who you think wouldn't be! It doesn't hurt to try! At the very least, all we can ask is for you to spread the word about our campaign! We can't thank you enough!

Thank you for your support!

story:
My name is Chris Matrone, I'm an award winning filmmaker and the Writer  & Director of 5 Doors. The film 5 Doors touches on subject matters that are extremely relevant to the times of today, yesterday, and tomorrow. The film discusses depression, suicide, forgotten ambitions, and the existential crisis we all face as go through our lives trying to make a name for ourselves and leave our mark in history.

What We Need & What You Get

Location fees, sets, & permits: Renting locations, building sets, and get permission to shoot in certain locations (permits). I'm not against breaking and entering, but not everyone is as cool as me.

Insurance: In case one of our actors or crew gets lost on this spiritual journey and we need to hire a rescue party.

Wardrobe: The clothes just don't make the man/woman/child/alien, it makes the movie!     

Makeup and Special effects makeup: The price of makeup adds up, and our makeup artists got to eat too. 

Post Production (sound mix, score, editing, etc.): Just because the curtain has closed, doesn't mean the show is over. The film's adventure never stops, as such the expenses for the film never ends as well.

Storage Drives: The raw footage has to sleep somewhere before it's turned into magic! 

Catering: The Cast and Crew would like to eat. While some of us can just rough it out days on end without food or water, some have enjoyed the finer things in life like having a full stomach after a hards day work. 

Film Festival Submissions: The expenses for a film never stop, even after filing and editing. To make sure this film's story is properly told, it's going to have to hit the festival circuit hard, and as any filmmaker can tell you, those festival submissions all start to add up.  

The Impact

This film was all about how life can affect us, and sometimes it feels like there is nowhere to go, so we run away. I was inspired to tell a story that I thought could speak to people dealing with the feelings of stress, depression, and suicide, especially with today's problems in society.  We often ignore these feelings or suppress them. Other times we see the warning signs, but we ignore the unfortunate truth, for a comforting lie. Regardless of our best efforts, everyone sometimes feels like we are ice skating uphill to an uncacheable goal. Other times we achieve our goals, yet we feel overwhelmed like we are flying too close to the sun like Icarus and find ourselves lost in the flames of our ambition. 

5 Doors starts out as a seemingly mundane and simple story that turns into a spiritual quest of redemption, self-realization, and the acceptance of one’s mortality.The biggest theme in this film is that second chances are possible, even if the second chances come at the very end of our journey. The films asks the question “Are you happy?” and if not, “What is happiness to you?”.  The message in this film is that It’s okay not to be okay, and you are never alone. Some people never learn that, and that is something that deserves to be changed. 

Risks & Challenges

Let me start off by saying that even if this campaign doesn't raise a penny, this film will happen. Regardless of this film being a passion project of mine, I firmly believe that the message behind this film is something everyone should hear. Suicide, depression, apathy towards life, these are feelings that everyone has felt. I know I've felt it. I wrote this film as an outlet for my own depression and thoughts of suicide. I was once told to take my pain and make it art, so that's what I did.

The beauty about Indiegogo is that it's flexible and every dollar we earn we can put it towards the film. Anything from a dollar helps this production be even better, and everyone behind it is more than grateful to anyone who donates, invests, supports, or just helps spread the word. 

The 5 Doors Team

CHRIS MATRONE

DIRECTOR/WRITER/PRODUCER

Chris Matrone is a New York based multiple awards winning filmmaker and has been working in the film industry from his late teens to his entire adult life. Matrone best know for his work with the award winning production company "Transcending Pictures", the "Hudson Valley International Film Festival", and the up incoming NYC production company "It Was All a Dream Entertainment". 

IMDb: Chris Matrone

Sandra Lucas

Producer

Sandra was born in New Zealand but has lived for more than half of her life in USA. She has many wonderful theatre roles and television commercials to her credit. She is also known for her role on "One Life to Live" as Mrs. Hughes. She is a skilled martial artist with a black belt in Nihon Goshen Aikido.

IMDb: Sandra Lucas

History

In the past, I had worked as an A.D. and co-writer on many of the awards winning sets with the talented production company Transcending Pictures. In my time there we made three feature films and a short film. All of our films were award winning, or nominated, and had distribution offers throughout the years. Along side working with Transcending Pictures in the film industry, I had also been co-owner/Operations Director of The Hudson Valley International Film Festival and had helped lead it through 2 successful years in the beautiful city of Monroe, NY. Below is sizzle reel of my experiences and the work that I had done over the years.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't help by donating money, we would love for you Tweet about our film and its campaign, share it on Facebook, Instagram, Snapchat, Google Plus or whatever other social media juggernaut is taking control over the masses. Raising awareness is an important part of making this movie, and it's even more important to raise awareness about depression and suicide. These are things that can't be ignored.

story:
AN IMPORTANT STORY TO BE TOLD, NOW

In a small town in Southern India, when Kartik, a young gay man, comes out to his conservative mother Vasudha, she has no one to turn to dispel her own fears and self doubts, and understand her loving son’s truth. She has to find her own ways to deal with her intolerant husband Damodar and the unforgiving traditional society around her. ‘Evening Shadows (Surmaee Shaam)’ is a universal story about a mother-son bond and its emotional strength to withstand the ravages of time and the harsh realities of our society.

 

WHERE WE STAND NOW

Shooting for the film has been completed and post-production has been completed till edit lock. Background score and audio post production (dialogue clean-up, foley, sound effects) are in progress, but stalled due to paucity of funds. Color grading, VFX, credits and subtitling have to begin.

We need your support to make this film happen.

 

WHAT IS THE FILM’S USP:

  1. The film has been shot in exquisite locales in Southern India, which adds a new dimension – not only being evocative, but also rich in visual and aural subtexts, metaphors and symbols.
  2. The film has been conceived, written and produced by award winning team at Solaris Pictures - Sridhar Rangayan (director, producer, writer) and Saagar Gupta (creative director, writer, producer, lyricist) who have to their credit several acclaimed LGBTQ films (Pink Mirror, Yours Emotionally, 68 Pages, Purple Skies, Breaking Free)
  3. The film’s lead actors Ananth Mahadevan and Mona Ambegaonkar are veterans with years of experience and greatly respected by audiences across India. The film’s young lead Devansh Doshi and Arpit Chaudhary are bright actors who hold a great promise for future.
  4. The composer of the title song Shubha Mudgal is a very renowned singer who is very popular.
  5. The crew boasts of accomplished professionals with mainstream, acclaimed film credits: DOP - Subhransu Das (Poorna, Filmistaan), Editor - Pravin Angre (B.A.Pass, Shagird, Ahista Ahista, Breaking Free - National Award winner), Sound Design - Madhu Apsara (Badlapur, Stanley Ka Dabba, Johnny Gaddar - Filmfare Award winner)
  6. The film’s trailer released in May has gone viral with around 50000 views on Facebook and 9000+ views on YouTube
  7. The film has already received a good media coverage. Check news links HERE

 

HOW MUCH DO WE NEED

We are raising $15,000 (approx INR 1,000,000) through crowdfunding on Indiegogo.

The film is an independent low-budget film with a total budget outlay of $120,000 (INR 7,700,000). The film has been partly crowdfunded (pre-production crowdfunding of about $15,000), self investment ($52,500) and a private investor ($7500). Apart from this proposed post-production crowdfunding of $15,000 we are also tapping four more private investors contributing $7500 each.

HOW WILL IT BE USED

FILM LINKED WITH ADVOCACY

By supporting this crowdfunding campaign, you are not only supporting the film Evening Shadows, but also help kick-start a movement in India similar PFLAG. The film is linked with advocacy efforts to form an organized Parents' Support group in Mumbai and later elsewhere in India. 

In the first round of crowdfunding for Evening Shadows production, carried out in November, 10% was set aside to form a support group for parents of LGBTQ persons in Mumbai.

On February 11th, a workshop was held, bringing together 10 parents, to discuss the issues they face and how they can form a group to help other parents. Check album HERE

Following up on this, a panel discussion was held on May 27th at 8th KASHISH Mumbai International Queer Film Festival. Watch video HERE

10% of funds raised with this Indiegogo campaign will support programs of the Parents' Support Group in Mumbai.

 

DIRECTOR'S STATEMENT

Evening Shadows is not only about a son coming out to his mother, but about how the mother tries to come to terms with this harsh truth, which is against all her beliefs and ingrained moral values. On another level, the film is also as much about the mother ‘coming out as a woman’, and claiming her due place within a traditional patriarchal society, and giving space for her own aspirations and opinions.

In India, especially in smaller towns, there are no support groups (like PFLAG), no information or guidance available, no one to turn to. Myths, social taboos and religion complicate matters further. The film tries to unravel the issues in a dramatic and sensitive manner, while still being entertaining to a mass audience. This is a film for every parent and family across India and across the world.

We hope the viewers take home a sensitive story that offers insight and hope about relationships that are put to test by life’s realities and shifting shadows of time.

 

OTHER WAYS YOU CAN HELP

Please share the campaign and help us in spreading the word.

Do tag us on

Facebook: /EveningShadowsFilm

Twitter: @EveningShadowsFilm 

 

DIRECTOR / PRODUCER'S PROFILE

Sridhar Rangayan wears many caps – of a filmmaker, writer, activist and festival director. He has consistently strived to give a voice to social issues in India through his films, writings and public speaking for over two decades.  

His award winning films The Pink Mirror, Yours Emotionally, 68 Pages, Project Bolo, Purple Skies and Breaking Free present hard-hitting social issues with warmth, compassion and humor; and are at the forefront of India’s emergent queer cinema movement. His latest film BREAKINGFREE won the National Award for Best editing (non-fiction) and was also selected for the prestigious Indian Panorama by Directorate of Film Festivals, Government of India. 

He has served as Jury for prestigious film festivals such as Outfest (USA), Berlinale (Germany), Iris Prize (UK) and Movies That Matter (Netherlands). 

Rangayan was one of the Grand Marshals of Montreal Pride 2016 and had the honour of meeting Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau.

He is the Founder Festival Director of KASHISH Mumbai International Queer Film Festival, which has over 7 years, become the biggest LGBTQ film festival in South Asia and an important event in Mumbai’s cultural calendar. It is the first and only mainstream LGBTQ film festival in India and the first LGBTQ film festival to receive clearance from government.

He is one of the Co-Founders of The Humsafar Trust, which was founded in 1994 and still is one of India’s largest community based organization working on HIV/AIDS intervention. He served on its board for 19 years. He also was one of the core team members of Bombay Dost, India’s first gay magazine that was launched in 1990. 

He has figured in the list of ‘Global List of LGBT Influencers’ by BFI Flare, UK; ‘5 most influential gay & lesbian Indians’ by Pink Pages, India; and ‘21 heroes changing LGBTI Asia for the better’ by Asia LGBT Milestone Awards, Hong Kong.  

Filmography  

  • The Pink Mirror - Gulabi Aaina ( 40 mins, 2003)
  • Chakkad Bakkad Bumbe Bo (120 mins, 2004) 
  • Yours Emotionally! (86 mins, 2006) 
  • 68 Pages (90 mins, 2007)  
  • Bridges of Hope (14 mins, 2008)
  • Project Bolo (20 interviews x 30mins, 2011)
  • Purple Skies (66min, 2014)
  • Breaking Free (82min, 2015)

Awards   

  • National Award for Best Editing 2016 (for 'Breaking Free')
  • Human Rights Award at qFLIX Philadelphia, USA (for ‘Breaking Free’)
  • Silver Remi award at Worldfest 2008, Houston, USA (for ‘68 Pages’)
  • Best Film on Social Issues at Ahmedabad Int. Film Festival 2009 (for '68 Pages')  
  • Bronze Remi at Worldfest 2005, Houston (for ‘Chakkad Bakkad Bumbe Bo’)
  • Jury Award for Best Film at ‘Fire Island Film Festival 2004, New York, USA (for ‘The Pink Mirror)  
  • Best Film of the Festival award at ‘Question de Genre’ 2003, Lille, France (for Pink Mirror)  
  • RAPA award for Best Telefilm, 2000 (for ‘Khamoshiyaan’, Zee TV) 
  • RAPA award for Best Comedy, 1999 (for ‘Piya Ka Ghar’, Zee TV)

 HOW MUCH DO WE NEEDWe are raising $15,000 (approx INR 1,000,000) through crowdfunding on Indiegogo.The film is an independent low-budget film with a total budget outlay of $120,000 (INR 7,700,000). The film has been partly crowdfunded (pre-production crowdfunding of about $15,000), self investment ($52,500) and a private investor ($7500). Apart from this proposed post-production crowdfunding of $15,000 we are also tapping four more private investors contributing $7500 each.HOW WILL IT BE USEDFILM LINKED WITH ADVOCACYBy supporting this crowdfunding campaign, you are not only supporting the film Evening Shadows, but also help kick-start a movement in India similar PFLAG. The film is linked with advocacy efforts to form an organized Parents' Support group in Mumbai and later elsewhere in India. In the first round of crowdfunding for Evening Shadows production, carried out in November, 10% was set aside to form a support group for parents of LGBTQ persons in Mumbai.On February 11th, a workshop was held, bringing together 10 parents, to discuss the issues they face and how they can form a group to help other parents. Check album HEREFollowing up on this, a panel discussion was held on May 27th at 8th KASHISH Mumbai International Queer Film Festival. Watch video HERE10% of funds raised with this Indiegogo campaign will support programs of the Parents' Support Group in Mumbai. DIRECTOR'S STATEMENTEvening Shadows is not only about a son coming out to his mother, but about how the mother tries to come to terms with this harsh truth, which is against all her beliefs and ingrained moral values. On another level, the film is also as much about the mother ‘coming out as a woman’, and claiming her due place within a traditional patriarchal society, and giving space for her own aspirations and opinions.In India, especially in smaller towns, there are no support groups (like PFLAG), no information or guidance available, no one to turn to. Myths, social taboos and religion complicate matters further. The film tries to unravel the issues in a dramatic and sensitive manner, while still being entertaining to a mass audience. This is a film for every parent and family across India and across the world.We hope the viewers take home a sensitive story that offers insight and hope about relationships that are put to test by life’s realities and shifting shadows of time. OTHER WAYS YOU CAN HELPPlease share the campaign and help us in spreading the word.Do tag us onFacebook: /EveningShadowsFilmTwitter: @EveningShadowsFilm  DIRECTOR / PRODUCER'S PROFILESridhar Rangayan wears many caps – of a filmmaker, writer, activist and festival director. He has consistently strived to give a voice to social issues in India through his films, writings and public speaking for over two decades.  His award winning films The Pink Mirror, Yours Emotionally, 68 Pages, Project Bolo, Purple Skies and Breaking Free present hard-hitting social issues with warmth, compassion and humor; and are at the forefront of India’s emergent queer cinema movement. His latest film BREAKINGFREE won the National Award for Best editing (non-fiction) and was also selected for the prestigious Indian Panorama by Directorate of Film Festivals, Government of India. He has served as Jury for prestigious film festivals such as Outfest (USA), Berlinale (Germany), Iris Prize (UK) and Movies That Matter (Netherlands). Rangayan was one of the Grand Marshals of Montreal Pride 2016 and had the honour of meeting Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau.He is the Founder Festival Director of KASHISH Mumbai International Queer Film Festival, which has over 7 years, become the biggest LGBTQ film festival in South Asia and an important event in Mumbai’s cultural calendar. It is the first and only mainstream LGBTQ film festival in India and the first LGBTQ film festival to receive clearance from government.He is one of the Co-Founders of The Humsafar Trust, which was founded in 1994 and still is one of India’s largest community based organization working on HIV/AIDS intervention. He served on its board for 19 years. He also was one of the core team members of Bombay Dost, India’s first gay magazine that was launched in 1990. He has figured in the list of ‘Global List of LGBT Influencers’ by BFI Flare, UK; ‘5 most influential gay & lesbian Indians’ by Pink Pages, India; and ‘21 heroes changing LGBTI Asia for the better’ by Asia LGBT Milestone Awards, Hong Kong.  Filmography   
The Pink Mirror - Gulabi Aaina ( 40 mins, 2003)
Chakkad Bakkad Bumbe Bo (120 mins, 2004) 
Yours Emotionally! (86 mins, 2006) 
68 Pages (90 mins, 2007)  
Bridges of Hope (14 mins, 2008)
Project Bolo (20 interviews x 30mins, 2011)
Purple Skies (66min, 2014)
Breaking Free (82min, 2015)
Awards    
National Award for Best Editing 2016 (for 'Breaking Free')
Human Rights Award at qFLIX Philadelphia, USA (for ‘Breaking Free’)
Silver Remi award at Worldfest 2008, Houston, USA (for ‘68 Pages’)
Best Film on Social Issues at Ahmedabad Int. Film Festival 2009 (for '68 Pages')  
Bronze Remi at Worldfest 2005, Houston (for ‘Chakkad Bakkad Bumbe Bo’)
Jury Award for Best Film at ‘Fire Island Film Festival 2004, New York, USA (for ‘The Pink Mirror)  
Best Film of the Festival award at ‘Question de Genre’ 2003, Lille, France (for Pink Mirror)  
RAPA award for Best Telefilm, 2000 (for ‘Khamoshiyaan’, Zee TV) 
RAPA award for Best Comedy, 1999 (for ‘Piya Ka Ghar’, Zee TV)

story:
Short Summary

I've acted and shot films throughout my life, and trained in production and screenwriting at the University of Michigan, where I made a thesis film, "The Leaders and the Rest" (Ann Arbor is almost as great as Manhattan).  After graduating, I shot a feature-length web series, "The Year of the Phoenix," which is available on YouTube.  I also worked at a post-production facility in SoHo (ironically, in the same building where my parents met in 1982).

Then, I took a break from production to focus on my acting.  I've performed in plays and short films throughout NJ and NYC, and founded a nonprofit theater company dedicated to diversity, Dragonfly Multicultural Arts Center, with my mom.

Now I'm ready to get back to my love of production with this idea that's been on my mind for about five years.  But I want to do this the right way in order to create the best possible film, and that means:

  • renting a high-end camera (in our case, a Blackmagic)
  • renting or buying sound equipment
  • renting lighting equipment
  • paying crew
  • keeping cast and crew well-fed
  • paying rental fees for some authentic NYC locations
  • art-directing and purchasing costumes to create a true early-'80s look

Our current cast includes Shauni Ramai, Nathaniel Tomb, and Aaron Ogle.  Our current crew includes Katie Nahvi and Matt Levy (with lots more TBA!).

What We Need & What You Get

  • Most of our funding will go toward renting a Blackmagic kit and some attendant lighting and paying our crew, who are NYC-based professionals
  • We also plan to rent a specific club that was around in the '80s; an abandoned luncheonette run by an art collective; and giving a small fee to a NYC native with an apartment where we want to film
  • We want you to feel like part of our team!  That's what our perks are geared toward.

The Impact

  • Our crew are all hardworking, NYC-based professionals.
  • Our cast is diverse and the script tells stories beyond that of our millennial protagonist.
  • All locations are in the five boroughs, and we want to spotlight the experiences of New Yorkers, beyond the typical Midtown/FiDi gloss.
  • I previously shot a feature-length webseries ("The Year of the Phoenix") on only $3K, so imagine what we can do with this!
  • As both an actor and a director (with an AD keeping an eye on things!), I'm dedicated to creating an efficient, safe, fun shoot for our cast and crew.  And I'll keep everyone well-fed!

Challenges

  • NYC is expensive, and no doubt we'll run into unexpected challenges and expenses along the way.  But I come from a run-and-gun filmmaking background, and like to look for creative, efficient, and--where possible--cheap ways to solve problems.
  • We plan to reach out to local restaurants for in-kind donations of food/sponsorships, thus spreading the news of restaurants to our cast and crew.

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Share this link on social media
  • Contact me about being a background actor on this project
  • Volunteer any locations, costumes, or props ('80s computers?) you have that might work!
